Confessionally Reformed Theology

Confessionally Reformed Theology

Johannes Hoornbeek (c. 1666) on God

[Institutiones Theologicae Ex Optimis Autoribus Concinatae (ex officinâ Francisci Moyardi, 1658)]

Table of Contents:

  • Chapter III: Concerning God
  • I. After the Scripture, the principle of knowing true and perfect Theology, the head of this everywhere first is God.
  • II. In divers manners is God in the Scripture denoted by names, of which the chief are verily Jehovah, which is peculiar and incommunicable to God only, Elohim, God, and so forth.
  • Question: Another question which is wont to be moved here is, whether the name Jehovah was known ere the time of the departure of the children of Israel out of Egypt.
  • Instance. But Moses doth so name Him in that place, for that it was so revealed unto him, not for that the name was known afore him.
  • Instance. What then is to be replied unto the passage in Exod. 6:2?
  • The final question is, whether the name Jehovah be so peculiar unto God, that it cannot be communicated unto creatures?
  • Objection 1. But that name is sometimes ascribed unto Angels, as in Gen. 18:1, one of those three Angels which appeared unto Abraham is called Jehovah. Also in Exod. 3:8, that Angel which appeareth unto Moses is so named.
  • Objection 2. But this name was bestowed upon an altar built by God, Exod. 17:15. ‘Then Moses built an altar, and called the name thereof Jehovah-nissi.’ And in Ezek. 48:35. ‘The name of the city from that day shall be, Jehovah is there.’
  • Objection 3. The passage in Jer. 33:16. ‘And this is the name whereby she shall be called, Jehovah our righteousness.’
  • Question. It is here questioned whether in the Holy Scripture of the Old Testament, by the word Elohim, there be denoted more persons in God?
  • III. God is a being, infinitely perfect; the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.
  • IV. God is one only.
  • V. We are brought unto the knowledge of the divine essence by His attributes and properties, which, by comparison and advancement made from creatures upward, are ascribed unto God in the most excellent way.
  • VI. But those attributes are in God, and are altogether the same with Him, neither diverse among themselves nor from God, for that through essence God is that which He is: but they are distinguished only in relation unto us, by reason of the feebleness of our conceptions concerning God.
  • VII. For God is most simple and void of all composition.
  • He objecteth, among other things, that in God there be divers immanent actions, which can scarcely be said to be the essence of God itself, as knowing, willing, loving Himself, and such like.
  • Objection. In God there be three Persons, or relative essences, and one absolute essence. Therefore, God is not purely simple.
  • Objection. In God there is begetting and being begotten. Therefore, divers things.
  • VIII. God is an incorporeal Spirit.
  • IX. Theologians do establish the distribution of divine attributes in divers manners, some as negative, others as affirmative; primary, secondary; a priori or a posteriori; in being what or as what; absolute, relative; abstract, concrete.
  • Question. Here it is asked whether all these have been in God from eternity?
  • Question. A question of the greatest moment is, whether the divine properties be communicable unto creatures?
  • X. Since we have described the essence of God, that He is an infinitely perfect being; now let us consider more nearly His several attributes, which do together connote infinite perfection: and first, that God doth live, but with an intellectual life, whereby He knoweth, willeth, can, with the added mark of perfection, all things: that He is the most perfect being, and infinite in essence; eternal in duration; present everywhere by immensity: of the same infinite goodness, holiness, and justice, which come under the name of virtues; then of power, and finally, unchangeably blessed in Himself. And first, God doth live, yea, He is life itself.
  • XI. God doth understand by Himself; and knoweth all things.
  • Objection. How then doth God know sin?
  • Question. A question of greater weight is moved by the Socinians and Vorstians against the Orthodox: whether God doth certainly foreknow future contingent things, especially those actions and events that depend upon the free will of men?
  • XII. God also doth will, with one act, whatsoever He willeth.
  • Question. Therefore, it is asked whether this permission be bare permission? Also, whether it be rightly opposed unto will, to wit, God did not will this, but permitted it?
  • Objection. But God doth command that men and devils sin. Therefore, He willeth it: for what one commandeth, that he willeth. For example, He did command Shimei to curse David, 2 Sam. 16:10. He did command Satan to be a lying spirit in the mouth of Ahab’s prophets, 1 Kings 22:22.
  • Question. Since, therefore, with one eternal and unchangeable decree He hath established all things that God willeth to be or not to be, how can God’s will be said to be manifold?
  • Question. But here it is asked whether the will of sign and of good pleasure be sometimes contrary one to the other? For that God sometimes seemeth to will by the will of sign that which He doth not will by the will of good pleasure, or the contrary whereof He willeth.
  • XIV. God is absolutely the most perfect being, to whom whatsoever is attributed is present in the most perfect manner.
  • Objection: But God made all things for Himself, Proverbs 16:4. Therefore, He seemeth not perfect by Himself alone.
  • XV. God is infinite in every way and in essence.
  • XVI. He is eternal, lacking beginning, succession, and end.
  • Objection: But God is called autoōn, from Himself.
  • Question. Whether God’s eternity be without any change and succession, and is all at once?
  • XVII. And the essence of God is immense, not confined nor excluded by any spaces of things or places.
  • Objection: The Scripture itself in many places seemeth altogether to affirm that God, by reason of His substance, is only in heaven.
  • Objection 2: It is unworthy of God to be present in filthy places with His most pure essence; and the very majesty of God seemeth to require that He have His essence abstracted from these earthly and filthy things; for otherwise He seemeth to be mixed with those things and to become part of them.
  • Objection 3: If God be infinite, where then is He outside the world, since there is no place there?
  • XVIII. Just as other attributes, so virtues are attributed unto God: goodness, holiness, justice, etc.
  • Question. It is here asked whether the justice that recompenseth punishment for sin be a natural property of God, which God cannot deny; or some indifferent thing, which God can admit or omit without harm unto His nature?
  • Objection: If this justice be natural unto God, then He will necessarily exercise it against all sinners, nor can He suspend punishment nor forgive sin.
  • Objection: But it is lawful for any to remit his right. Therefore, God also can do it.
  • XIX. God is also of infinite power.
  • XX. Now, whatever God is, He is immutably.
  • Objection: The essence of God is changed; for God was made man, that is, the Son of God was made man, changed, therefore, with a new substantial perfection acquired.
  • XXI. Finally, God is eternally blessed in and from Himself.
  • XXII. That which pertaineth unto the exposition of the divine essence in the abstract: the catholic faith is that it is common unto the three Persons, that God is one, the Persons three: Father, and Son, and Holy Spirit.
  • Walaeus poseth the question: Whether it be lawful to use such words here, which be not found in the Scripture, since in this mystery it is not lawful to speak beyond the Scripture?
  • XXIII. The divine Persons are distinguished both among themselves and from the essence by a true distinction, but inexplicable unto us, and not to be expressed by any terms or notions except very imperfectly, according unto our manner.
  • XXIV. The Persons are distinguished among themselves by personal properties; as the Father, who is not a Person from another, begot the Son, and with the Son breatheth forth the Holy Spirit; the Son is begotten by the Father, and with Him breatheth forth the Holy Spirit; the Holy Spirit proceedeth from both.
  • XXV. But the Trinity of Persons in God is proved from the Scriptures by arguments both general, which teach it, and special, concerning the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit separately.
  • XXVI. The Son and the Holy Spirit, although they be Persons from another, yet have the same common essence with the Father, which is from itself, and therefore be rightly called autotheos.
  • Objection: John 17:3.
  • Objection. The third argument that they bring forth against the Holy Trinity is from 1 Corinthians 8:6, where the Holy Spirit clearly teacheth that there is one God the Father, from whom are all things, who is also distinguished from Christ, insofar as Christ is one Lord, through whom are all things. Therefore, Christ is not that one God who is the Father.

Chapter III: Concerning God

I. After the Scripture, the principle of knowing true and perfect Theology, the head of this everywhere first is God.

TRELC. The second principle of sacred Theology is God; we say ‘second’ not in the order of Nature, for nothing is prior to God, but for the betterment of our knowledge, because as the primary instrument of all saving knowledge concerning God is the Scripture, so the primary and supreme principle of being for those things which serve this knowledge is God, from whom all things directly depend.

PROF.In Sacred Theology, God is treated not merely as the principle of its foundation or of our knowledge, but as the subject and the foremost and principal topic of Theology, from whom the others proceed, under whom they are included, and to whom they should be related. Therefore, from this, Theology itself deriveth its name.

II. In divers manners is God in the Scripture denoted by names, of which the chief are verily Jehovah, which is peculiar and incommunicable to God only, Elohim, God, and so forth.

GOM. For albeit God, by reason of the infinite excellence of His nature and the limited acuity of the created mind, cannot be fully comprehended, and consequently cannot be perfectly expressed by word or name, wherefore He was aptly termed ‘nameless’ by the ancients (for what is His name, if thou knowest? Prov. 30:4), nevertheless, certain names of God are found in the Scripture, Exod. 3:14-15 and 6:3, whereby He hath represented Himself through a certain suitable analogy (that He might be known and adored by us according to our measure unto salvation). Gregor. Nazian. Oration 36, or 2 on the Son. The proper name of God, which pertaineth unto Him only, Ps. 83:19, common and everlasting, Exod. 3:15, Ps. 135:13, even יהוה, which is not only more ancient than the former ‘Eheje,’ but also more fitting by the differentiation of the word from its verb; whether it be derived from היה by the mutation of yod into vav, as A. Efra. upon Exod. 15:2, or from הוה with the same meaning. That name of God, not to be hidden but to be reverently remembered, He entrusted unto the children of Israel: forasmuch as He calleth it His memorial, Exod. 3:15, Hos. 12:5, and with it thrice repeated, to be blessed by the priests unto the people, Num. 6:24-26, and unto the people, even to swear by it in holiness, He commanded, Deut. 6:13 and 10:20, Josh. 9:19. Touching the right pronunciation thereof, as the learned do contend, so the controversy remaineth yet undecided. For certain affirm that ‘Jehova’ is the true pronunciation: others, contrariwise, deny it and maintain that the vowels annexed unto this name are not its own, both parties upheld by their respective arguments. Even as we deem that the second opinion ought to be tolerated, so we do not hastily esteem that the first should be favored. The first cause is, that the vowels of the name Jehovah, written with the consonants, may agree with them (no less than with its own name Judah): neither is there any necessary ground wherefore they should be accounted as alien vowels. Which thing shall be plainly perceived from the scrutiny of the contrary view. The second is, that the former and half part of the name Jehovah, to wit, Jeho, doth appear with the selfsame points in words compounded thereof, and is read by all, beyond dispute, after the same manner. Names of this sort, therefore, are termed by the most renowned Drusius ‘ikophora,’ ‘programmatophora.’ Such as יהונתןJehonathan, and in contraction יונתן Jonathan (which signifieth ‘given by God,’ Deodatus), and many others like unto them. The third cause is from the witness of the Seventy interpreters: who from the words of Jer. 23:6, יהוה צדקנו ‘Jehovah our righteousness,’ did form the name from Jehovah and tsedek ‘righteousness,’ ἰωσεδέκ (with ω instead of Jeho, by contraction, agreeable to the custom of writing and the nature of the Greek tongue). The fourth cause is from the ancient practice of the Jews. Who, being guided by a certain prohibited religion, did refrain from uttering the complete name Jehovah: hence, they did pronounce that part thereof which was present in words compounded from it, and was freely spoken in them, with like freedom, for the entire Jehovah, to wit, ‘laho,’ and in Greek ἰαω. Diodorus, in his Bibliotheca, book 1, chapter 1; Theodoret, in his fifteenth question on Exodus; and Therap., in book 2, do change ש jeva not into c, as is frequent, but into a gentler sound, à. Even as the Seventy did utter δαδών for דדן and שבא; Num. 32:38, Nabo for נבו; Gen. 10:7, שמואל as σαμεήλ, 1 Sam. 1:20. Lastly, contrariwise, from the twisting back of the objection to this first reason, a fifth argument doth arise in favor of the former opinion. For if Jehovah did bear the points of the name אדני Adonai, then in like manner, the first point would not be simple Sheva, but with Patach: even as, since assuredly the points of the name אלהים Elohim, the first thereof, is fittingly Sheva with Segol.

WAL.

Question: Another question which is wont to be moved here is, whether the name Jehovah was known ere the time of the departure of the children of Israel out of Egypt.

Answer. The occasion of doubting is from Exod. 6:2, wherein God doth witness unto Moses that He appeared unto their fathers by the name of Shaddai, that is, God Almighty; but by His name Jehovah He was not known unto them. But that this is not the intent of that passage, that the name Jehovah was not employed by God aforetime, is shewn from Gen. 2:4. ‘When Jehovah God had not sent rain upon the earth, and there was no man to till the ground.’ And in chapter 4:1. ‘Adam knew Eve his wife; and she conceived, and bare Cain, and said, I have gotten a man from Jehovah.’

Instance. But Moses doth so name Him in that place, for that it was so revealed unto him, not for that the name was known afore him.

Answer. That cannot be, for Moses doth recount the words which Eve herself did use at the birth of Cain. And in Gen. 15:7, he doth relate the words of God Himself unto Abraham. ‘God appeared unto Abraham, and said, I am Jehovah, that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees.’ See likewise Gen. 18:13 and 26:25.

Instance. What then is to be replied unto the passage in Exod. 6:2?

Answer. There, truly, it treateth not of the word or the usage of the word Jehovah, but of the fulfillment of that which is signified thereby. For God had verily promised the land of Canaan unto the Patriarchs aforetime, but He had not sent them to possess it, which at last He did by Moses. Thus also unto us who believe in Christ, He is not only El Shaddai, sufficient to accomplish the promises, but also Jehovah, that is, the bestower of those blessings which are promised in Christ.

The final question is, whether the name Jehovah be so peculiar unto God, that it cannot be communicated unto creatures?

Response. The Samosatenians do deny it, and Vorstius likewise denieth it in his book concerning attributes. But the most grave authors do affirm it, and well nigh all the Hebrews and Greeks also, and it is a most potent argument for the Godhead of the Son and of the Holy Spirit. The reasons be these:

1. For it is the proper name of God, and it hath all the characteristics of a proper name. For it beginneth with the letter yod, which is used in the formation of proper names, as Jacob, Isaac, and such like. Moreover, it doth not admit suffixes at the end, nor the emphatic he at the beginning, neither hath it a plural form. But a name that is proper unto God cannot be imparted unto creatures.

2. For that the thing signified by that name doth appertain unto no creature, to wit, to be and to exist of oneself, to be eternal and unchangeable, even as John doth expound it, Rev. 1:8. And the cause of all things and the fulfiller of promises, as it was seen from Exod. 6:2.

3. From the passages afore cited, Exod. 3:15. ‘This is my name for ever, and this is my memorial unto all generations.’ Isa. 42:8. ‘I am Jehovah, that is my name, and my glory will I not give to another.’

4. For that no instance can be brought forth from the Scripture wherein it is communicated unto any creature.

Objection 1. But that name is sometimes ascribed unto Angels, as in Gen. 18:1, one of those three Angels which appeared unto Abraham is called Jehovah. Also in Exod. 3:8, that Angel which appeareth unto Moses is so named.

Answer. We deny that it was a created Angel unto whom this name is given: but it was the very Son of God, and the Angel of the covenant, even Christ. Which all the circumstances of those passages do teach. For in Gen. 18:25, He is adored by Abraham, and is called the Judge of all the earth. In Exod. 3:15, He is called the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob. And He that was tempted by the Israelites in the wilderness is plainly called Christ, 1 Cor. 10:9. The like reason holdeth for similar passages, chiefly Isa. 6:3.

Objection 2. But this name was bestowed upon an altar built by God, Exod. 17:15. ‘Then Moses built an altar, and called the name thereof Jehovah-nissi.’ And in Ezek. 48:35. ‘The name of the city from that day shall be, Jehovah is there.’

Answer. These be titles conferred upon the altar and upon the city, which were tokens of the divine presence and protection. Therefore, it is a metonymical speech, whereby sacramental signs do bear the name of the thing signified. Furthermore, not only the word Jehovah, but the entire sentence was written upon the altar and assigned unto the city by this sacramental phrase: which hath no likeness unto the naming of Angels, as they do urge.

Objection 3. The passage in Jer. 33:16. ‘And this is the name whereby she shall be called, Jehovah our righteousness.’

Answer. The passage is to be rendered differently, to wit, the pronoun denoteth not ‘this,’ but ‘he’: so that the meaning is: ‘He that shall call her the city after his own name is Jehovah our righteousness,’ and that is Christ, who is there promised, even as in the foregoing chapter 23.

There followeth the word Elohim, the origin whereof is either from El ‘strong,’ or from alah ‘to swear,’ for that He is the one by whom men do swear: or from the Arabic Aliha, which signifieth ‘to worship,’ as it were σέβασμα ‘object of worship.’ The singular is not El, as some suppose, for that hath Elim, but Eloah, which is seldom found, whereas Elohim is more common. Therefore, Elohim doth signify a judge endowed with the mightiest power. This word is at times ascribed unto Angels and men, for that God hath in some manner communicated His power unto them, as is well known, see Exod. 4:16, Ps. 8:6 in comparison with Heb. 2:7, Ps. 82:1, and so forth, touching Kings, judges, Angels, the thing is manifest.

Question. It is here questioned whether in the Holy Scripture of the Old Testament, by the word Elohim, there be denoted more persons in God?

Response. This is denied by the Jews of this day, and by the Samosatenians, and with them also Bellarmine, and our Drusius, in a small book written purposely upon this subject. Nevertheless, we, together with Zanchius, Junius, Sohnius, and others, do deem the other opinion which affirmeth this to be the better. Our arguments be these:

Reason 1. Zanchius doth adduce this reason at the commencement of book 2 concerning the three Elohim: it is not probable that Moses did not set forth at the beginning of the history of the creation of things the sufficient cause of the creation of all things, which the Prophets and Apostles did set forth in other places. But not only the Father, but also the Son and the Holy Spirit are the cause of the creation of things, as is evident from many passages of the Old and New Testament, chiefly John 1:3, Col. 1:16, which do appear to have respect altogether unto the passage in Moses. Therefore, Moses also did express it at the beginning, when he said, ‘In the beginning, Elohim created.’

2. If the word Elohim did signify but one Person, even as the word Jehovah doth signify one essence, then also it might be said that Jehovah is one Elohim, as it is said that Elohim is one Jehovah. But the Scripture never speaketh thus. See Deut. 6:4. ‘Jehovah our God, Jehovah is one.’ Therefore, and so forth.

3. The word Elohim in the Scripture is never employed of virtues or attributes when it treateth not of the true God, but always of persons, as Angels, judges, false gods, by a certain concession and imitation. Therefore, when it is spoken of God, it is understood only of persons.

4. The additions and diverse construction which are found in these manners of speech do shew that there is something mysterious herein. For the word Elohim is not only joined with a singular verb, as in Gen. 1:1, ‘In the beginning, Elohim created,’ but also with a plural, as in 2 Sam. 7:23. ‘What one nation in the earth is like thy people, even like Israel, whom Elohim went to redeem for a people unto himself?’ Likewise, Josh. 24:19. ‘Ye cannot serve Jehovah, for He is holy Elohim.’ Even as in Gen. 1:26. ‘And Elohim said, Let us make man in our image’: wherein He cannot be speaking unto Angels, for man was not created after their image, neither was he created by them. Therefore, one person doth address others.

5. And albeit in Hebrew, the plural is oftentimes used for the singular in the second and third persons, yet it is never so in the first person, as Aben Ezra, the chief of grammarians among the Hebrews, doth confess at the beginning of Genesis. Neither doth Kimchi, who gainsayeth this, adduce any example to the contrary that is pertinent, for they are understood by syllepsis, as Junius doth shew in his Treatise on the Trinity, defense 2, section 3. But in this mystery, the word Elohim and Adonim is also spoken in the first person concerning God, as in Exod. 20:2. ‘I am Jehovah thy God,’ Gen. 3:22. ‘Behold, the man is become as one of us,’ Gen. 11:7. ‘Go to, let us go down, and there confound their language.’

GOM. The origin of the word θεός is set forth by the most ancient writer Herodotus, in Euterpe, edition 11, Stephanus page 69, and by the Etymologist, from θέω ‘I dispose,’ with a suitable analogy unto the signification of the word Elohim as delivered by the Hebrews.

MACC. Touching the word ‘Deus,’ it is asked whether the word ‘Deus’ doth signify essence and nature, or rather office, dignity, and power. We do affirm the former: the arguments for this be these:

1. That name whose sure etymology cannot be demonstrated doth signify essence, not power: the cause is, for that all words which denote dignity and office are derived from others, as ‘King’ from ‘ruling,’ ‘Lord’ from ‘lording’: but the sure etymology of the word ‘God’ cannot be demonstrated: for all that are given are allusive, not genuine.

2. If the word ‘God’ were a name of office and dignity, it would be a concrete not synonymous, but paronymous, for that synonymous concretes do designate substance and nature, paronymous ones office and quality: but the name of God is a synonymous concrete and not paronymous: for it hath a synonymous abstract, as ‘Deity’ is the synonymous abstract of ‘God’: therefore, even as the abstract doth denote essence, so also the concrete.

3. Appellations taken from office and dignities are applied unto the substance not directly, but indirectly, when it hath already received its essential name: but there is no other substantial intermediate name whereby this is imposed upon it: therefore.

4. If the word ‘God’ were a name of office and not of essence, it would follow that it pertaineth unto the supreme Deity only in relation unto creatures: but it is certain that it pertaineth unto Him absolutely, for God was before all creatures.

5. For that unto such as are called gods, our God is set in opposition as essential, 1 Cor. 8:5-6, and by the title of the true God, John 17:3, He is distinguished from them: wherefore also the Galatians are rebuked, because, when they were yet Gentiles, they did worship those which by nature were not gods: nevertheless, all these things are to be understood of the proper and natural signification of the word: for improperly, the term ‘God’ is used of those who are such only by office, as is well known.

III. God is a being, infinitely perfect; the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

TRELC. From the consideration of the names of God, we do proceed unto the explication of the thing itself, or the description of God Himself. But God is, as the Hebrews do define most succinctly, Ichova Elohim, Exod. 3:13-15, that is, one essence of three Persons. Of this description, there be two parts: one concerning the essence and the Unity of the essence; the other concerning the Persons and the Trinity of Persons: which two cannot be severed from the explication of the divine Nature; neither ought they to be confounded together. For even as there is the supreme and indivisible Unity of the divine Essence in the plurality of Persons (for the being of the Father is the being of the Son and of the Holy Spirit), so there is a real and distinct distinction of Persons in the unity of the essence, for to be the Father is not to be the Son or the Holy Spirit.

JUN. They who have derived aught from the holy letters never did move the question whether God be essence, but only whether essence may be spoken of God, since (as they said) the Scripture maketh no mention of God’s essence: but albeit the word ‘essence’ is not expressed in so many letters in the Scripture (which is untrue, Prov. 8:14), nevertheless, for that equivalents are found therein, θειότης ‘divinity,’ Rom. 1:20, θές φύσις ‘divine nature,’ Gal. 4:8, μορφή θεοῦ ‘form of God,’ Phil. 2:6, and derivatives of the word itself, as are the names of God, Jehovah, Iah, Eheie, ὤν or αὐτοών ‘the being’ or ‘the self-being’: we say that the word ‘essence’ was of old used by the servants of God in this mystery, and is now used, in a holy and pious manner. It is the property of the one God to be, who only is, who is ὤν, and αὐτοών, that is, Jehovah, Exod. 3:14, Rev. 1:4. And whatsoever entity there is (if we may so say) in all things, that is, from Him and in Him. For in Him we live, and move, and have our being: from whom, in whom, by whom, and for whom are all things, Acts 17:28, Rom. 11:36. Yea, so peculiar unto God is being, that He doth not even possess being, which is proper unto creatures, but He is being itself. Wherefore, not so much concrete terms are spoken of God as abstract ones: as light, truth, wisdom, and such like.

AMES. The essence of God is that whereby He is the absolutely first being, Isa. 44:6. ‘I am the first and the last, beside me there is no God.’ Rev. 1:8 and 21:6, 22:13. ‘I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the end, the first and the last.’ This essence is denoted by the name Jehovah.

IV. God is one only.

AMES. But for that the essence of God is such, hence it followeth that God is one and only. Deut. 6:4, 1 Tim. 2:5, Eph. 4:6, 1 Cor. 8:5-6, Mark 12:32, Rom. 3:29-30. He is called one, not in kind, but by that most perfect unity which in creatures is wont to be called numerical and individual.

JUN. But we say ‘only,’ to shew that we speak not of one as it is the beginning of number and hath relation unto other numbers that follow, but as it is convertible with being, and addeth no thing unto being, but only denieth all division thereof.

GOM. And therefore, gravely, as many things, Tertullian, against Marcion, book 1, chapter 4: ‘Christian truth doth distinctly declare that if God be not one, He is not.’ Whether it be rightly said that God is one in number? Basil, in his Epistle 141 unto Caesar, and Rufinus in his Exposition of the Creed, N., others do affirm. We would rather say distinctly, if ‘one in number’ doth denote ‘only,’ we affirm. But if with the Philosopher, in the Categories, chapter 2, it signifieth an individual or one among many of the same kind, we deny. Therefore, is God better called only and singular than one in number? We affirm, by reason of the ambiguity of this phrase, whereof Aristotle, in the Topics, book 1, chapter 7, and in the Metaphysics, book 4, chapter 6.

CALV. It is true that the name of the one God was everywhere known and renowned. For they who did worship a great multitude of gods, whensoever they spake from the genuine sense of nature, as though they were satisfied with one God, did simply use the name of God, and this was wisely observed by Justin Martyr, who for this end did compose a book concerning the Monarchy of God, wherein from many witnesses he doth shew that the unity of God was engraven upon the hearts of all: The same also is proved by Tertullian from common speech.

V. We are brought unto the knowledge of the divine essence by His attributes and properties, which, by comparison and advancement made from creatures upward, are ascribed unto God in the most excellent way.

JUN. Attribute, in this place, we take not for any predicate that might be spoken of God, but for properties proper unto God, in the fourth manner, unto Him only and ever, whereby the truth of the essence is made known in itself and distinguished from others. Of that method whereby God, by the instructions of nature and Scripture, doth lead us unto the excellency of the knowledge of Himself, there be three parts or degrees. The first is of negation, when, not being able to know what God is, we consider what He is not, taking away those things which seem not to befit Him. The second is, when, by reason of the same infirmity of ours, that we might have some knowledge of God other than negative, we do attribute unto God whatsoever we see to carry some nobility. The last is, when, knowing that those things which we attribute unto God cannot be in Him as they are in us, whatsoever we do speak concerning God, we speak equivocally. Unto this last attribute doth pertain being most perfect, which doth denote the supereminent manner whereby we ought to regard all properties, both affirmatively and negatively spoken concerning God.

AMES. For that the essence of God cannot be sufficiently comprehended by us by one act, it is expounded by us as though it were manifold: to wit, through many attributes. They are called attributes, for that they are said rather to be ascribed unto God than to be properly in Him, if they be taken as the words do sound. For from those things which we see to be in creatures, we do attribute some unto God, and remove others from Him.

VI. But those attributes are in God, and are altogether the same with Him, neither diverse among themselves nor from God, for that through essence God is that which He is: but they are distinguished only in relation unto us, by reason of the feebleness of our conceptions concerning God.

JUN. These properties, thus, do distinguish the essence of God from others, in such wise that they are not distinguished really either from the essence of God or among themselves. Not from the essence: for they are in one essence in such manner that they are the essence itself: for whatsoever is in God is not among themselves, but simply is: for God would be divisible, which is contrary unto nature and unto the Scripture. But that we do consider in God many attributes in number, that is from the goodness of God, who did will that we, whom He knew to know all things by successions, and consequently by parts, and therefore not able to know His indivisible essence, should consider in His same essence as it were parts, which are only spoken by analogy. But those analogical and imaginary parts are called by us attributes, for that, so that God might be more manifest unto us, the Scripture did attribute them unto God for our sakes.

MACC. The attributes which are spoken of God are God Himself; wherefore then, might one say, do we teach that there be so many attributes of God, seeing that God is one only and most simple? Answer. This doth happen not from the nature of God, but from the manner of our conceiving; to wit, whatsoever our mind doth grasp is finite; for the infinite cannot be comprehended by the finite: therefore, we are constrained to consider those diverse things in God which in His essence are one and the same, even as in the marketplace, a countryman, by reason of ignorance, is constrained to cut golden coins into smallest parts, as into small coins, a great heap whereof doth equal the gold: such is clearly the condition of our mind when we think upon God. But that the attributes of God be God Himself, we do shew at this time by these arguments. Holiness is God Himself, therefore no cause can be given why eternity, infinity, should not be God Himself. For the same reason that applieth unto one attribute in God applieth also unto another. But that holiness is God Himself, we do demonstrate thus. Heb. 6:13. The Apostle saith, God, when He made promise to Abraham, because He could swear by no greater, swore by Himself: but God did swear by His holiness, Amos 4:2. Therefore:

1. The holiness of God shall be God Himself.

2. Eternity is God Himself.

Therefore every attribute that is in God is God Himself: the reason is the same as for the former: the antecedent is evident from 1 Sam. 15:29.

SPANH. Attributes be the very essence of God, represented unto us through divers inadequate concepts. Thus, infinity is not the want of a term, but the divine essence itself, apprehended as wanting all term and definition; so omnipotence is the essence of God itself, apprehended as wanting all hindrance in acting; and eternity is the essence of God itself, as wanting all term in enduring, and so for the rest. But the divine essence is said to be represented Applying this rule, as the words do sound, represented through divers inadequate concepts, both for that otherwise they would be altogether synonymous words if they did represent the divine essence in wholly the same manner through all, and for that our understanding doth form for itself a different formal concept when it conceiveth justice, another when it conceiveth mercy.

VII. For God is most simple and void of all composition.

JUN. Simplicity is first, for that it doth exempt God from the category of substance, which is first in order: but it doth exempt Him, for that both substances, whereof that predicament is spoken, are composed: the one, of matter and form, which do constitute the body, and of quantitative parts, by the composition proper unto bodies; the other, not by the composition of bodies, but yet of essence and being, substance and accident. But God is not corporeal, for that He is pure act, whereas every body is in potentiality. And He is Spirit, John 4:24, which is set in opposition unto body. Not composed of essence and being, for if His being were not the same as His essence, His being would stand unto His essence as act unto potentiality, since being (as they say) is the actuality of every form or nature. But in God, nothing is in potentiality, but all are act.

TRELC. Simplicity in God is utterly indivisible and absolute, admitting no diversity or composition of parts or accidents, neither in Himself, nor in the Persons, nor in the operations.

WAL. We do plainly deny that God is composed by any manner of composition. Our reasons be these:

1. Whatsoever is composed is composed by another: but God could not be composed by any, for that He is the first being and dependeth upon none.

2. Every composed thing is later than its composing parts, but the essence of God cannot be later than itself or than any other thing.

3. Every composed thing can be dissolved into those things whereof it is composed; but God is absolutely unchangeable.

4. The essence of God is in itself and of itself most perfect. Therefore, nothing can be added unto it that should make it more perfect.

These reasons are taken from the unshaken principles of Sacred Theology, and therefore He is also absolutely called Jehovah, Eheie, and light, truth, wisdom, justice. Vorstius, by reason of the foregoing arguments, doth indeed confess some simplicity in God, but not of every kind: to wit, not that which is from subject and accidents, also from nature and supposit.

He objecteth, among other things, that in God there be divers immanent actions, which can scarcely be said to be the essence of God itself, as knowing, willing, loving Himself, and such like.

Answer. These eternal and essential actions in God are the very essence of God in act. For the essence of God cannot be considered as a thing diverse from all these acts, but must be considered as comprehending all these eternal acts in its nature. Neither are those faculties in God at any time without these second acts, as it is in man: but they are always active with a perpetual and indefinite act; and therefore they are the divine essence itself living and endowed with these acts.

Instance. But the decrees of God are in God, and they are divers: yet the divine essence is one only.

Answer. Indeed, the decrees in God are divers if we consider the objects about which the decrees of God do turn, for by one decree God did determine to create the world, by another to preserve it, by another to raise up fallen man: but even as God in the knowledge of simple intelligence did contemplate all things that could be and could not be with one act; so also with one act He did choose from all those through His one decree what He willed to be or not to be, what He decreed to do, or to permit and to order.

Instance. But the decrees of God are free. The essence of God is necessary; therefore, the essence of God cannot be His decree.

Answer.This difficulty is so great that certain learned men do prefer here to withhold judgment rather than rashly to affirm aught: and therefore, albeit it is certain that these are in God and have been from eternity, yet how they are in Him is not to be inquired, so long as they be not said to be in God as accidents, as was before shewn. Yet others do attempt also to meet this difficulty thus: the decree of God, whereby things without God were decreed to be at some time, is indeed free; for God could will to create the world or not to create it, to create it in this manner and at this time or another: but since this decree is also eternal, in it two things are to be considered, first, the very inexistence of the decree in God; second, its respect or relation unto divers objects. Considered in the former manner, the decree of God is necessary; for it is the very active essence of God, which hath been employed from eternity about those divers objects. In the latter manner, this decreeing essence is considered with varied respect unto the things to be decreed or decreed, and in this varied respect there is freedom: but this respect or relation is not an absolute being, but relative and of reason only; and therefore it is not a true absolute accident, neither doth it imply any composition, but only a distinct way of considering the same divine understanding and will. Even as the understanding of man or his will, turning unto practical things, doth not thereby take on a new real accident, but only a new respect of the same faculties. If this be so in man; therefore, much more divinely can it be in God.

Instance. But that respect is either essence or accident. If essence, it is not free; if accident, we have some accident in God.

Answer. There is given a third thing in things, to wit, the mode of the thing, which is a being of reason, and implieth no composition. Even as the eye, turning unto visible things, doth not thereby receive some new real accident in itself, but only a new mode of its essence, whereby it freely turneth itself rather hither than thither.

Objection. In God there be three Persons, or relative essences, and one absolute essence. Therefore, God is not purely simple.

Answer. The antecedent is denied: for in God there is indeed one absolute essence and three relations, but not relative essences.

Instance. But every relation is a being, and every being hath an essence.

Answer. I deny that every being hath a distinct essence, for thus there would be a progress unto infinity. Being hath essence, essence again hath essence, and so forth. Therefore, they may be called entities, or rather modes of being, but not essences.

Instance. But those relative entities joined with the absolute essence do compose that essence, or at the least the three Persons.

Answer. I deny that they compose the essence or the Persons, but they do constitute the Persons and distinguish them one from another. For composition is a sign of imperfection in things that are composed. Distinction is a sign of perfection, for that it is opposed unto confusion. But the Persons indeed do differ really one from another, but from the essence only by mode or reason, which hath its foundation in the thing, not in the understanding only, that is, by reasoned reason, not by reasoning reason only, as the Scholastics do say. Furthermore, this also must be added, that these relations are divine: and therefore do far surpass the created understanding. Justin Martyr doth call them modes of subsisting, the Scripture itself calleth them ὑποστάσεις ‘hypostases,’ wherein we must rest content, and here religious ignorance is better than presumptuous profession of knowledge.

Objection. In God there is begetting and being begotten. Therefore, divers things.

Answer. We grant that there be divers things in God, but not absolutely, but relatively, which relation doth constitute and distinguish the thing, doth not, properly speaking, compose it: but begetting and being begotten are not of the essence, but of the Persons.

Instance. Therefore, at the least there shall be something in God besides the essence.

Answer. To wit, something relative, not absolute: for in God there is not other and other, but another and another.

Instance. If begetting be not other than the essence, therefore neither shall being begotten be other than begetting: and thus the Father shall be the Son, and the Son shall be the Father: for things that are the same with some third thing are also the same one with another.

Answer. That axiom is true when the things that are the same with some third thing are the same with that third thing both in reality and in reason. But the divine essence is indeed the same in reality with the Persons, for the Persons have a common essence; but it is not the same in reason with the Persons: which even in created things doth suffice to establish a real distinction between things: as a ray is the same in reality with its light and with its heat, yet light and heat are not the same: for heat and light are distinguished from the ray by a certain reason. Likewise, understanding and will are really distinguished one from another, albeit from the essence of the soul, according to the most eminent Philosophers, they are distinguished only by reason.

MACC. There is nothing in God that is not God. The adversaries (such as the Socinians) do rise up against this, and say that this proposition, ‘whatsoever is in God is God,’ is not a proposition of the Prophets and Apostles: foolishly, forsooth, as though that which is necessarily deduced from those things which the Prophets and Apostles did teach concerning God should not be referred unto the Prophets and Apostles: but such is this proposition, which is deduced from the infinite perfection and immutability of God asserted in the Scripture. For suppose there be something in God that is not God, this shall surely be an accident, and if the adversaries do not fear to admit this, they shall also admit that the divine essence is not of itself perfect in every way and infinite, forasmuch as it is perfected by accidents; likewise, that it is not altogether unchangeable, for it shall be changed according to the accidents whereunto it is subject; for who doth prevent an accident from being taken away (especially a common one, which they call separable, such as they do establish many to fall into God) from the subject? The Scripture doth not so think of God, that He can be varied and changed into many forms, whether essential or accidental; ‘The heavens shall perish, but thou shalt endure,’ saith the Prophet, ‘thou shalt change them, and they shall be changed, but thou art the same, and thy years shall not fail:’ and James in his Epistle writeth, ‘with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning;’ unto which also it pertaineth that John saith, ‘God is love,’ 1 John 4:8-10, by which manner of speech he doth indicate that love is not an accident, but the very essence of God: for we cannot affirm accidents of subjects in that wise: for we never say, ‘man is whiteness,’ but ‘white,’ but it is said that God is love itself.

VIII. God is an incorporeal Spirit.

WAL. It is asked what manner of essence God is, whether corporeal or incorporeal? Of old, the Anthropomorphites did assert the former, for that in the Scriptures, human form and members are sometimes ascribed unto God: Vorstius also did assert this in our time: but that both do greatly err is proved by the arguments that follow. 1. For the holy Scripture doth expressly testify that God is a Spirit. John 4:24. ‘God is a Spirit, and they that worship Him must worship Him in spirit and in truth:’ and the Father of spirits, Heb. 12:9. ‘Furthermore, we have had fathers of our flesh which corrected us, and we gave them reverence: shall we not much rather be in subjection unto the Father of spirits, and live?’ Where the word ‘Spirit’ is set in opposition unto flesh, and by Christ, Luke 24:39, it is expressly said that a spirit hath not flesh and bones. 2. For every body is visible, but God is invisible, 1 Tim. 1:17 and 6:16. ‘Whom no man hath seen, nor can see.’

AMES. He is called spirit, negatively, for that He is not a body. 2. Analogically, or by a certain likeness; for in spiritual substances there be many perfections that do more shadow forth the divine nature than anything corporeal can.

IX. Theologians do establish the distribution of divine attributes in divers manners, some as negative, others as affirmative; primary, secondary; a priori or a posteriori; in being what or as what; absolute, relative; abstract, concrete.

GOM. The attributes of God are either primary or secondary. Whereof, the former are negative, which do denote the perfection of God indirectly, through the negation of imperfection: the latter are affirmative, which do directly signify the perfection of God.

AMES. But perfections of this sort, which are signified by negative names, as infinity, immensity, do always include in their material signification not only the negation of imperfection but also the affirmation of the greatest perfection: for which cause they are also properly called attributes.

TRELC. Of these properties, some do denote the essence unto us, as a priori, both negatively, as infinity, and affirmatively, as simplicity. Others as a posteriori, and that both properly, as those which are in God primarily and of Himself, Power, Knowledge, Will: and improperly, as those which are spoken of God by transference and according to anthropopathic likeness, such as love, anger, and the like.

WAL. Some are spoken absolutely of God, as all the foregoing: others relatively: which relation is twofold; either with respect unto the Persons among themselves, as Father, Son, Holy Spirit, or with respect unto creatures unto God, as Creator, Savior, Lord, King, and such like.

Question. Here it is asked whether all these have been in God from eternity?

Answer. Those which are attributed absolutely unto God are all eternal, as also those which are relative unto the Persons themselves: as shall be proved hereafter against the heretics, Arians, Samosatenians, and the like. Therefore, the difficulty remaineth only in those which are spoken of God with respect unto creatures, concerning which we answer: If the foundation of the relation be considered, as the creative, conserving, ruling power, that also is eternal; for it is referred unto absolutes: but if the formal relation; that did come in time: for God was not an actual creator, save when the things were created.

Instance. But thus it is established that something hath been added unto God, and therefore some change hath been made in Him.

Answer. That relation with respect unto God is not real, but only with respect unto the creature: for something real is added unto the creature, not unto God, but only some notional concept. Augustine doth adduce a like example of a coin: when it becometh a pledge, nothing real is added unto the coin, but unto the man who receiveth it, something real is added. Thomas doth adduce a like example of a column, which is on my right when I turn unto it from that side; yet nothing real is therefore added unto the column, but only unto the man, who turneth himself unto it in this or that manner, change is added. Other names are spoken abstractly of God, as truth, justice, life, light; and others concretely, as just, wise, truthful, living. By the abstracts, simplicity and perfection are denoted: by the concretes, their actual existence in God. For in creatures, abstracts do not subsist, but with a degree of intensity and remission. Howbeit, that which is of perfection is in this manner indicated in God.

Question. A question of the greatest moment is, whether the divine properties be communicable unto creatures?

Response. Of old, the Arians did assert this, who did claim that the power of creating all things could be communicated unto a mere creature, and was indeed communicated unto the Son of God, whom they did impiously set forth as a mere creature; even as today the Ubiquitarians do contend that the divine properties, and among them also ubiquity, are really communicated unto the body of Christ. But since the divine properties are of two sorts, either absolutely incommunicable, or communicable in a certain respect, that is, of which like ones are created by God in creatures; yet we do assert that neither, if considered absolutely and as they are in God, can be communicated unto creatures.

AMES. But for that an attribute is a formal perfection of the divine essence, therefore neither those relations which have respect unto creatures, nor those which are called personal, are to be reckoned among the attributes. Those attributes which do include in their formal something proper unto the divine essence are plainly incommunicable, as omnipotence, immensity, eternity, and such like: those which are said to be communicated unto creatures do agree with them by analogy, not altogether in the same manner as they are in God, neither yet altogether equivocally.

X. Since we have described the essence of God, that He is an infinitely perfect being; now let us consider more nearly His several attributes, which do together connote infinite perfection: and first, that God doth live, but with an intellectual life, whereby He knoweth, willeth, can, with the added mark of perfection, all things: that He is the most perfect being, and infinite in essence; eternal in duration; present everywhere by immensity: of the same infinite goodness, holiness, and justice, which come under the name of virtues; then of power, and finally, unchangeably blessed in Himself. And first, God doth live, yea, He is life itself.

JUN. Perfections that are in creatures are affirmed of God by analogy. But since there be none more noble than those which God did create in His image, from the nature of intelligent forms, we shall speak concerning God that He is intelligent, omnipotent. All things that are in the world are either animate or inanimate: the former do excel the latter, by all reckoning. Therefore, life must be spoken of God. For if He be eternal, He liveth, since the definition of eternity is (as it is asserted by Boethius) the complete and perfect possession of interminable life all at once: which the Scripture doth confirm, calling God the living God, and the fountain of life, and life, Ps. 36:9, 1 John 5:20. But for that the vegetative life of plants and the sensitive life of animals are corporeal, God, who is spirit, is not to be said to live the life of plants or animals; rather, since the life of intelligent forms is the noblest of all, by analogy, we do attribute intelligent life unto God. According to the same analogy, since we see from the life of Angels there doth emanate as from a source a double operation, whereof one remaineth in the operator, as understanding and willing; the other proceedeth unto an external effect: we shall first affirm of God understanding and will, then power, which is considered as the principle of operation proceeding unto an external effect.

AMES. God is called living:

1. For that God doth operate most of all from Himself, not moved by another.

2. For that the vital action of God is His essence itself.

3. For that He is the source unto other living beings of all entity and vital operation. Acts 17:25, 28. ‘He giveth to all life, and breath, and all things: in Him we live, and move, and have our being.’

He is said to live by Himself, for that He receiveth from none, in any part, either being or living. Hence the chief title of God, whereby He is distinguished from all idols, that He is the living God, Deut. 32:40, Ps. 84:2, Jer. 5:2. Therefore, our faith, seeking eternal life, doth rest in God alone, for that God is the fountain of all life. John 5:26.

XI. God doth understand by Himself; and knoweth all things.

JUN. That there is intelligence in God, the most wise order of things, which cannot be from brute nature, doth sufficiently demonstrate. The simplicity of God, whereby we know Him to be the purest and most simple act, and consequently, remote from all matter, doth teach that God is intelligent, since it is certain from nature that the more immaterial forms are, the more intelligent they are. The Scripture also calleth God wise, knowing, the fountain of wisdom. Rom. 16:27, 1 Sam. 2:3, Ps. 36:9, and doth mention the depth of the knowledge of God, Rom. 11:33. Of this knowledge of God, albeit it is not a quality, but the very essence of God, one in itself and indivisible, we do establish a double mode, for the sake of alleviating our weakness. One is that whereby God hath equal knowledge of Himself, He knoweth adequately what He is; and He is what He knoweth Himself to be: He knoweth Himself through Himself. 1 Cor. 2:11. The other is that whereby, with one act, not successively, eternally, not in time, through His essence, not through the reception of intelligible species, immutably, not contingently, He knoweth what are, and what are not yet but shall be, with the knowledge of vision, that is, He seeth them as present unto Himself; and those which are not and shall not be, He knoweth insofar as He knoweth whatsoever He can do, and what can be done by His creatures with His permission: all good things, knowingly and practically; all evil things that are done by creatures, knowingly only: the order of both good and evil unto a good end, beneficially. But that He knoweth both good and evil is sufficiently evident from that He is the universal principle of all origin and act, insofar as it is good: the Lord of the universe, wherein, if He be truly Lord, nothing doth happen without His knowledge: which the Scripture also doth intimate in many places, Prov. 15:3, Heb. 4:13.

GOM. The knowledge of God is that whereby He doth most perfectly comprehend every and all knowable things (that which can be known) with one infinite and simple act of understanding. Wherein the object and the adjoined mode of knowing do appear distinctly. The object of God’s knowledge is the first (that which can be known), all and entire. All, for it doth include God, Matt. 11:27, 1 Cor. 2:10-11, and the rest besides Him, 1 John 3:20, Ps. 139:11-12, 16, Jer. 16:17 and 32:19, Matt. 10:29-30. Entire, for not in part, but thoroughly, He doth know Himself and all things with all their circumstances. Wherefore it is rightly called omniscience, under which object are contained not only things past and present, but also things future, Isa. 46:9-10, and all possible things, and things future from hypothesis, or, given a condition, what would come to pass, not only necessary from a necessary cause, but also contingent from a contingent cause, 1 Sam. 23:12, Matt. 11:21. All which things God doth embrace with the infinite light of His essence. But the adjoined mode of knowing is the comprehension of all and the whole known thing, with one act, not finite nor composite, but infinite and simple. So that from Himself, through His essence, He doth know all things, altogether and at once, like unto an eye, most perfectly. Wherefore He is commonly called the first truth, and wisdom, Rom. 11:33, by reason of His excellence. For His works are known unto God from eternity, Acts 15:18. He beholdeth the ends of the earth, and all that is under heaven, Job 28:24. Neither is there any creature invisible in His sight; but all things are naked and open unto His eyes, Heb. 4:13. He searcheth the hearts and reins, Jer. 17:10. He understandeth thoughts from afar, Ps. 139:2. His understanding is infinite, Ps. 147:5. He knoweth all things, 1 John 3:20. And therefore, God is asserted to be the only wise, Rom. 16:27, by excellence, because of His singular preeminence, for that no intelligent creature’s acuteness doth comprehend from itself all things, entirely, and at once.

TRELC. Knowledge in God is that whereby He knoweth Himself in Himself, and outside Himself all and singular things through Himself, with an individual and immutable act. For God only knoweth and understandeth Himself, Matt. 11:27, with the most intimate and perfect act, infinite, comprehending Himself infinitely: yet when He doth comprehend Himself by understanding, the understanding of God whereby He comprehendeth is not other than He Himself whom He comprehendeth, for being, understanding, comprehending, are reciprocal. He also knoweth outside Himself all and singular things in common and distinct knowledge, Heb. 4:13, of matter, form, and accidents both good and evil: but through Himself He knoweth good things, and evil things through the opposite good. Yet He knoweth both Himself and others with an individual act, insofar as with one act of understanding, and with a total simultaneous intuition, He doth embrace the entire distance of things, whether local or temporal, possessing all things at once and always, which among us are unfolded in times. And this individual and present knowledge of God, in God unchangeable, is of both contingent and necessary things: imposing the lot of contingency upon contingent things, as also the law of necessity upon necessary things.

AMES. The faculties are understanding and will. Wherefore faith doth rely upon Him who knoweth what we need and also willeth to supply it. The understanding of God is simple, without any composition, discourse, or representation of species, Heb. 4:13. ‘All things are naked and open unto His eyes.’ The understanding of God is unchangeable: He doth not know one thing otherwise or more than another, nor more afore than now, or now than afore, Acts 15:18. ‘Known unto God are all His works from the beginning of the world.’ The understanding of God is eternal: it neither beginneth nor endeth, as there. The understanding of God is infinite, for He doth perceive all truths and reasons of all things, Job 11:8-9. ‘The wisdom of God is higher than heaven, longer than earth, broader than the sea.’ See Ps. 139:6.

PROF. But He knoweth with a simple and one, unchangeable, infinite, and eternal act: that is, all things, always, at once and together, and necessarily, Acts 15:18, Heb. 4:13, so that He doth ignore nothing, learn nothing, doth not advance, is not deceived, doth not opine, forget, remember, yea, He doth not even properly foreknow. Ps. 90:4, 2 Pet. 3:8, Isa. 40:14. Although with respect unto future things He is truly said to foreknow, of past things to remember, of present things to know: not that He doth understand and see one thing after another, or one from another successively. Wherefore, not only wisdom and understanding are attributed unto Him, Rom. 11:33, and He is called wise; but wisdom is with Him and is His, the only wise, 1 Tim. 1:17. He is called omniscient, knowing the hearts, Acts 15:8, and is the fountain and origin of all wisdom, Ps. 147:5, Dan. 2:20-22, Prov. 2:6.

WAL. God doth know all things through His essence, not through species abstracted from things:

Reason 1. For the knowledge of God is eternal, but the abstracted species of created things are not eternal, since the things themselves are not eternal.

2. For the knowledge of God would have a cause without itself: which cannot be, since He is the cause of all things, and did order things from eternity before they were.

3. For God is the purest act, therefore He is not in potentiality to receive species from without.

4. For God doth know Himself most perfectly. Therefore, He also knoweth all things that are subject unto His power in themselves.

Objection. How then doth God know sin?

Answer. As a privative being, and departing from His holiness and purity. Therefore, not through a species of evil abstracted from evil, but through the contrary species of good.

Averroes also doth confess that all general things are known and cognized by God; but he dareth to deny that all singular things are exactly known by God: but that this opinion is absurd is shewn by the things that follow:

1. For the Holy Scripture doth clearly testify unto it, as Heb. 4:13. ‘Neither is there any creature that is not manifest in His sight: but all things are naked and opened unto the eyes of Him with whom we have to do.’ Likewise, Matt. 10:29. ‘Are not two sparrows sold for a farthing? and one of them shall not fall on the ground without your Father: but the very hairs of your head are all numbered.’ What is more singular? So Ps. 139:2. ‘Thou knowest my downsitting and mine uprising, thou understandest my thought afar off,’ and so in many other places.

2. God did create singular things, He doth care for and govern them; therefore, He knoweth them. God did choose Jacob, had Esau in hatred: He raised up Pharaoh to shew His power in him, Rom. 9:13. He did separate Paul from his mother’s womb, Gal. 1:15. Therefore, it is foolish even to think the contrary.

Question. A question of greater weight is moved by the Socinians and Vorstians against the Orthodox: whether God doth certainly foreknow future contingent things, especially those actions and events that depend upon the free will of men?

Answer. It is so clearly and firmly proved from the Scripture that it is marvellous that there be a Christian man who dareth to call it into question.

Reason 1. Deut. 19:5, if a woodcutter goeth out, and while cutting, the axe doth fly from his hand and slay a passerby, God is said to have delivered him into his hand. Likewise, Prov. 16:33. ‘The lot is cast into the lap; but the whole disposing thereof is of the LORD:’ so Matt. 10:29. ‘Not a sparrow falleth to the ground without your Father.’ These be concerning contingent things that depend not upon man’s will.

Reason 2. Concerning higher things that depend upon the will and choice of men, the matter is no less evident. Let these passages be seen: Ps. 7:9. ‘He searcheth the reins.’ 1 Kings 8:39. ‘Thou, even thou only, knowest the hearts of all the children of men.’ Prov. 24:12. ‘Doth not he that pondereth the heart consider it?’ And therefore, God is also called καρδιογνώστης ‘knower of hearts’ in many places of the Scriptures. And lest any should except that these be said of present thoughts of hearts, not of future ones, David in Ps. 139:2 doth expressly say, ‘Thou understandest my thought afar off.’ And v. 4. ‘For there is not a word in my tongue, but, lo, O LORD, thou knowest it altogether.’ Isa. 48:8. ‘I knew that thou wouldest deal very treacherously.’

Reason 3. It is taken from the faculty of God to predict future contingent things, whereby God doth distinguish Himself in many places from all false gods and creatures, Isa. 41:23. ‘Shew the things that are to come hereafter, that we may know that ye are gods.’ And yet Satan also, from present causes and conjectures, hath sometimes predicted some things. Thus Isa. 45:11. ‘Thus saith the LORD, the Holy One of Israel, and his Maker, Ask me of things to come.’ So John 14:29. ‘And now I have told you before it come to pass, that, when it is come to pass, ye might believe.’ But Christ had predicted His passion, which was also to happen through the intervention of human wills.

Reason 4. It is taken from many special predictions that are in the Holy Scripture, whose events also did regard human wills and their actions. Such as those concerning the calling and obedience of the Gentiles unto the church of Christ, many centuries of years before it came to pass, Gen. 9:27, and 49:10, Deut. 32:21. Concerning the hardening of Pharaoh’s heart and that of his ministers, that they would not let the Israelites go, Exod. 3 and following. Concerning the liberation of the Jews by Cyrus from the Babylonian captivity, Isa. 45:1. Concerning Josiah slaying the priests of the high places upon the altar of Jeroboam, 1 Kings 13:2. Concerning the predictions of Daniel, chapters 9 and 11, and in the New Testament, concerning the destruction of Jerusalem by the Romans, Matt. 24:2. Concerning the propagation of the Gospel through the whole world, Matt. 28:19, Acts 1:8. Concerning the rise of the Antichrist and divers heresies, 2 Thess. 2, 1 Tim. 4:1, in the Apocalypse in many places. All which and like things were to happen through human wills.

XII. God also doth will, with one act, whatsoever He willeth.

JUN. Of this will of God (as we did for knowledge), for the sake of our weakness, we do establish a double mode. One (unto which our natural will doth correspond in some sort, whereby we will to be and to live) whereby He willeth Himself, with an equal will, that He willeth to be eternally and unchangeably, and He willeth unchangeably and eternally to be what He is. The other is that unto which our will doth correspond, ἐκ προαιρέσεως ‘by choice,’ whereby He willeth all other things for Himself, most wisely and freely, to effect good things, to permit evil things, to lead good and evil things unto a good end, His glory, and the salvation of His own: for God doth not will to permit evils, save insofar as He knoweth and willeth that He can elicit good from evils.

TREL. Will in God is that whereby God freely and unchangeably willeth His glory as the end; and all other things as means unto this end. This will, since it is both of the end and of the means, is the first and supreme cause of things, including in itself the other causes and subordinating them unto that first cause. Although the will be one in one essence: yet from the reason of the objects and effects, good and evil, we do distinguish it into good pleasure and pleasure. For by reason of good effects, whereof God doth intend the end and the means primarily and per se, we call that will good pleasure, Eph. 1:5. But by reason of evil effects, wherein God doth intend the end primarily and per se, but not the means themselves save for the end, we call it pleasure, 1 Cor. 10:5.

AMES. The will of God is simple and unique in God, the will of God is unchangeable; for He always willeth the same and in the same manner, Ps. 33:11. ‘The counsel of the LORD standeth for ever,’ the will of God is eternal, for He doth not begin to will what He did not will afore, nor doth He cease to will what He willed afore. Mal. 3:6. ‘I am the LORD, I change not:’ the will of God can be called infinite; for it hath no external limitation. The affections that are attributed unto God in the Scripture, such as love, hatred, and the like, either do designate acts of will or agree with God only figuratively.

WAL. Concerning the evils that are in the world, it is asked whether God doth will them, or can be said to will and approve them? That this may be rightly understood, a distinction must be made between the evil of punishment and of fault. As touching the evil of punishment, God doth not will it insofar as it is affliction and misery of the creature, as He doth testify in Ezek. 18:23. ‘I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked.’ But insofar as it is the work of justice and the execution of His just judgment, to that extent He doth entirely will it and inflict it upon the creature: as Paul doth testify, Rom. 9:22. ‘What if God, willing to shew his wrath, and to make his power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction.’ And Isa. 1:24. ‘I will ease me of mine adversaries.’ And Prov. 1:26. Wisdom saith she will laugh at their destruction who did despise all admonitions. Even as a judge, when he punisheth a malefactor, doth not delight in the misery or affliction of the malefactor, and yet willeth it as the execution of justice and the vindication of public peace. This is also proved thence, that those punishments are the works of God: but God cannot but approve His works. The antecedent is evident of itself: and it is asserted in Deut. 32:39. ‘I kill, and I make alive.’ And Amos 3:6. ‘Shall there be evil in a city, and the LORD hath not done it?’ But concerning the evils of fault, the question is more difficult, and according to divers respects, even certain writers of the Reformed Church do speak differently. But that this may be rightly understood, three things are to be considered in every evil action.

1. The action itself as such.

2. The malice or deformity that is in that action.

3. The direction of that perverse action unto a good end, whether it be the testing of the sinner, or the punishment of the sinner, and both unto the glory of God.

As touching the first, the action, as action, is from God’s providence, for in Him we live, and move, and have our being: and therefore, to that extent, it is an indifferent thing and a natural good of itself, and therefore cannot but be approved by God; as the motion of a lame horse, as motion, doth proceed from the agent. But as for the third, to wit, the direction of the evil action unto a good end, that is from God: and therefore, God doth will it. Illustrious passages for this matter are in the example of Joseph, Gen. 50:20. ‘But as for you, ye thought evil against me; but God meant it unto good.’ And Isa. 10:5. ‘O Assyrian, the rod of mine anger, and the staff in their hand is mine indignation. I will send him against an hypocritical nation,’ etc. ‘Howbeit he meaneth not so, neither doth his heart think so; but it is in his heart to destroy and cut off nations not a few.’ Therefore, the chief difficulty lieth in the second respect, to wit, the very viciousness or form of evil that is in such actions: which, since it is a defect of good and of the order established by God, God neither approveth nor willeth it, but willingly permitteth it; for it is good to do good even from evils, and to permit evils for good ends. Therefore, God doth not will evil as evil, but He willeth and approveth His permission, for that is the work of the divine will. The first member, that God neither willeth nor approveth evil as such, is taught by express passages of Holy Scripture, as Ps. 5:4. ‘Thou art not a God that hath pleasure in wickedness.’ Also Hab. 1:13. ‘Thou art of purer eyes than to behold evil, and canst not look on iniquity,’ to wit, with approval; for otherwise God knoweth all things, both evil and good. Likewise, James 1:13. ‘God cannot be tempted with evil, neither tempteth he any man,’ that is, unto evils: then the same is invincibly proved from this, that God doth forbid and punish all evil or sin: but no one can forbid and punish that which he approveth. Therefore, when certain of the Reformed do say that God willeth also the actions themselves that are evil, and which with respect to men and devils are sins, this is necessarily to be understood of those things that were said afore, not of sins as sins. The second member, to wit, that God only permitteth evils, and indeed willingly permitteth them, the Holy Scriptures also do teach, as Ps. 81:12. ‘So I gave them up unto their own hearts’ lust: and they walked in their own counsels:’ others translate, ‘I permitted them to follow the counsels of their heart:’ which is nearer unto the text, and Acts 14:16. ‘Who in times past suffered all nations to walk in their own ways.’

Question. Therefore, it is asked whether this permission be bare permission? Also, whether it be rightly opposed unto will, to wit, God did not will this, but permitted it?

Answer. Beza seemeth sometimes to deny both. Therefore, this permission is never bare, as if God did permit something idly or unwillingly, but it is always joined with the direction of the vicious action itself unto good ends, as was explained above from Gen. 50:20 and Isa. 10:5. For God could not even allow evil to be, as Augustine doth rightly say, unless He could do good from evils. Neither is this permission rightly opposed unto will, if the word ‘will’ be taken for any action of will, for God doth not permit evil actions unto good ends unwillingly, but willingly and according to His decree: as Paul in Rom. 9:22. ‘What if God, willing to shew his wrath, and to make his power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of wrath fitted to destruction?’ As also the passage cited before from Ps. 81:12 doth clearly indicate. But if the word ‘will’ be taken for complacency and approval of the thing as such, which the Hebrews call ‘chaphets,’ then it is rightly said that God doth not will iniquity, but permitteth it, as God Himself speaketh in Ps. 5:4. More fully, permission is opposed unto effecting: as when we say, God did not do this, but permitted that it be done by the evil creature.

Objection. But God doth command that men and devils sin. Therefore, He willeth it: for what one commandeth, that he willeth. For example, He did command Shimei to curse David, 2 Sam. 16:10. He did command Satan to be a lying spirit in the mouth of Ahab’s prophets, 1 Kings 22:22.

Answer. In these and like places, the word ‘commanding’ is taken improperly, for the hidden governance and direction of divine providence. As in Jon. 2:10, God did command the fish to vomit out Jonah, that is, He so directed and governed the fish: for the fish is not capable of a command properly so called. And thus, it is excellently explained in Isa. 10:5-6. ‘O Assyrian, the rod of mine anger, etc. I will send him against an hypocritical nation, and against the people of my wrath will I give him a charge, to take the spoil, and to take the prey, etc.’ V. 7. ‘Howbeit he meaneth not so, neither doth his heart think so; but it is in his heart to destroy, etc.’ If God had commanded it by precept, then he would have known and thought it, and would have executed it without danger, whereas yet woe is denounced unto him for that. Thus, in the example of Ahab, God’s secret permission and direction is indicated, whereby He did loosen the reins unto Satan upon these prophets of Ahab, that he might be a lying spirit in their mouth, since he is the father of lies.

Properly speaking, there is but one will of God, for with one act He did will and decree from eternity all things that ever shall come to pass: as it is evident from this, that all God’s decrees are eternal and indeed unchangeable, as hath already been shewn.

Question. Since, therefore, with one eternal and unchangeable decree He hath established all things that God willeth to be or not to be, how can God’s will be said to be manifold?

Answer. This doth happen with respect unto the divers objects that are subject unto this will, and also with respect unto the divers modes whereby God’s will is explained and set forth unto us. Therefore, the first division, which is asserted by many authors, even the Reformed, is into the secret will and the revealed will. The secret will is called that of those things which God hath retained in His power, as Christ speaketh of the last day, Acts 1:7. But the revealed will is that of those things which are revealed unto us in the Old and New Testament. Moses doth mention both, Deut. 29:29. ‘The secret things belong unto the LORD our God: but those things which are revealed belong unto us and to our children for ever, that we may do all the words of this law.’ The former is called secret, either with respect unto things that are not yet revealed unto us, as concerning the last day of the world already spoken of, which are often afterwards revealed by God; or by the fact itself, as the last day shall be revealed by the fact itself; or by disclosure, as that book in Rev. 5, whose seven seals were opened in order, and first revealed unto Christ, and through Christ unto the Angel, and unto John, and through them unto the churches: or it is called secret with respect unto the causes why God doth act thus or thus: for God doth many things whose causes, beyond His will, He doth not want us to search or to know. The second celebrated distinction, of greater weight and use, used by the Scholastics and also accepted by our own, is the division into the will of sign and the will of good pleasure; which others call the will of decree and the will of precept: for that it doth more clearly express the nature of each member. The will of sign is called that whereby God hath signified unto men, both in the law and in the Gospel, what He willed to be done or not done by them, with the promise of life and other blessings annexed unto the obedient, and the threat of death and other curses made unto the disobedient. Durandus did express it in this verse: He commandeth, and prohibiteth, permitteth, counseleth, fulfilleth. The will of good pleasure is called that whereby God hath decreed what He Himself immediately willeth to do in man and concerning man, or what is certainly to be or not to be, whether this tendeth unto the salvation or condemnation of man: with the word ‘good’ referring not unto the event, but unto God’s counsel, which, whether it punisheth or bestoweth benefits, is always good: as the word εὐδοκία ‘good pleasure’ is used by Christ Himself, Matt. 11:26. That both are designated by the name of God’s will is evident from many places in Holy Scripture.
