Concerning the latter, to wit, of good pleasure, see the example, Isa. 46:10. ‘My counsel shall stand, and I will do all my pleasure.’ Likewise, Ps. 115:3. ‘Our God is in the heavens: he hath done whatsoever he hath pleased,’ Rom. 9:19. ‘Who hath resisted his will?’ and Eph. 1:11. ‘Who worketh all things after the counsel of his own will.’ Concerning the former, see the passage, Ps. 40:8. ‘Lo, I come to do thy will, O God.’ John 7:17. ‘If any man will do his will, he shall know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself.’ And 1 Thess. 4:3. ‘This is the will of God, even your sanctification.’ These things, therefore, are manifest.

Question. But here it is asked whether the will of sign and of good pleasure be sometimes contrary one to the other? For that God sometimes seemeth to will by the will of sign that which He doth not will by the will of good pleasure, or the contrary whereof He willeth.

Answer. Those wills are not contrary one to the other, for they are concerned with divers objects. For the will of sign is that whereby He sheweth what He willeth the creatures to do: but the will of good pleasure is what God Himself willeth to do in the creature or concerning the creature. For example, God willeth that a good son should will that his father not die, whom God by the will of good pleasure willeth not to live longer. But we must always attend unto the revealed will of God, until the secret will of God be made known unto us, and then also we ought willingly to submit unto it: as in the Lord’s Prayer we pray: ‘Thy will be done.’ And in Acts 21:14, the faithful in the city of Caesarea, when they heard that bonds were prepared for Paul in Jerusalem, and could not dissuade him from that journey, at last rested, saying, ‘The will of the Lord be done.’ Moreover, the will of sign is part of the will of good pleasure, and, so to speak, doth subserve it. But a part doth not fight with its whole. For by the will of good pleasure, God hath also decreed by what ways He willeth to invite man unto obedience to the Law and the Gospel, and by what degrees: for this also is from the will of good pleasure, that He willeth to operate further in one than in others. As it is clear from the parable of those invited to the wedding, Matt. 22, where some are only invited, some are also compelled to come.

XIV. God is absolutely the most perfect being, to whom whatsoever is attributed is present in the most perfect manner.

Verily, Junius saith: And this is the supreme perfection of the divine essence, whereby He is in Himself most perfect, self-sufficient, and without need. Forasmuch as God is being itself, nothing can be more perfect than He, even as nothing is hotter than heat itself; and since He is the efficient cause of all things, it is needful that the perfections of those things preexist in Him, according to the manner of supereminence.

Walaeus addeth: The attribute, as it were a certain summary of the rest, is the perfection of God. The word “perfection” is spoken from “perfecting,” and is unmeetly said of God; for “perfect” doth properly denote that which is fully made. In the tongue of the Greeks, it is teleion, that which hath received its end; in the Hebrew, it is better called Kelilah, from Kalal, to have all things. Therefore, that is named perfect to which nothing lacketh, and it is taken in twain ways: either absolutely or in a certain respect. Some do call it negative and privative. Absolute or negative perfection is that to which no perfection at all doth lack, which is in the nature of things or can be thought of. Perfection in a certain respect, or privative, is that to which nothing lacketh that is required for the full constitution of its nature. Thus is a stone called perfect, or gold, or a beast, and so forth, to which nothing lacketh that pertaineth to the constituting of its nature in that kind. All perfections of creatures are in God eminently; but to be in eminently is distinguished by the Scholastics from being in formally: for they say that those things are in formally which have the same form, as in glowing iron there is the form of fire; but eminently, those which have the same power, though not the same form, and that in a more eminent reason and manner: as in the sun there is the power of heating, of giving life, and suchlike; in a king, the power of all politic offices is eminently present, for all things depend upon him, albeit not all are exercised by him in the same wise as by others, his subjects, in whom they are formally present. But that this perfection is to be ascribed unto God, as hath been said, the places following do show:

1. For He is the efficient cause and fountain and preserver of all good things and perfections; but no man can give unto another that which he hath not in himself or in his power. Behold Romans 11:36, “For of Him, and through Him, and to Him, are all things.” James 1:16-17, “Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and cometh down from the Father of lights, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning.” In which saying not only are all perfect things said to be from God, but also all imperfection is affirmed to be absent from Him.

2. From places manifest: Psalm 94:9, “He that planted the ear, shall He not hear? or He that formed the eye, shall He not see?” Isaiah 66:9, “Shall I bring to the birth, and not cause to bring forth?”

3. Matthew 5:48, “Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect.” Psalm 16:2, “My goodness extendeth not to Thee,” that is, they bring nothing unto Thee. And Psalm 50:9, He saith that there is nothing among men that He needeth, nor hath He need to ask or receive aught from any. Acts 17:25 expressly saith that He is not in need of anything. Hence followeth the most consummate blessedness of God, which is the gathered possession of all good things and the fullest sense thereof.

Objection: But God made all things for Himself, Proverbs 16:4. Therefore, He seemeth not perfect by Himself alone.

Response: We deny the consequence, for He made them not to increase or help Himself, but to manifest and communicate; since the proper and greatest perfection of good is to communicate itself unto others.

XV. God is infinite in every way and in essence.

Junius proclaimeth: And verily, the measure of this divine perfection is infinity, since it is not determined nor circumscribed by any bounds, but exceedeth all things infinitely. Now infinity is partly of the essence itself in itself, partly with respect to extension. Of the essence in itself is both by reason of supereminence and by reason of power. By reason of supereminence, whereby it is called “being beyond being,” which infinitely transcendeth all categories and the dignity of other things, free from all matter and passive potency, which are the most ignoble of beings; but by reason of power, whereby God understandeth and can do infinite things, and in very deed doth them. And this indeed is the infinity of His essence. But of extension, one is according to place, which is called immensity; another according to time, which is eternity: of which the latter is of duration, the former is reductive of dimension.

Trelcatius saith: Infinity in God is not magnitude nor multitude that cannot be traversed, but immense power, or act, immensity, whereby He is not finite either outwardly nor inwardly, being wholly everywhere in Himself.

Gomarus declareth: Absolute infinity is a property of God’s essence, whereby it is not bounded by any limits of cause or measure. Whence there is a twofold manner of infinity. The first, whereby He is free from every cause, both outward and inward. Hence He is wont to be called “without beginning” and “without cause,” and in the same sense, commonly, though not enough accurately, He is denoted by the word “uncreated.” And verily, He is established as free from outward cause, for He is terminated neither by an efficient cause nor by an end. Not by an efficient cause, for before Him there is no God, Isaiah 43:10; nor can there be, for He is the first and the last, Isaiah 44:6-7. Not by an end, for He lacketh an efficient cause, and He is the utmost end of all things, and the chief good, Romans 11:36, Proverbs 16:4. But He lacketh an inward cause, for He consisteth not of matter and form. Not of matter, from which; for He is the author of all matter, Isaiah 44:24. Not of form, through which He existeth; for He hath neither an efficient cause from which, nor matter to be informed, into which it is brought, since He Himself is as it were form unto Himself, and all things: so that the form of God, Philippians 2:6, is nothing else than the infinite Deity itself. The second manner of infinity is that whereby He is immune from every measure of time and place. Which infinity is therefore distributed into eternity and immensity properly so called.

XVI. He is eternal, lacking beginning, succession, and end.

Junius affirmeth: The other kind of infinity is eternity, whereby God is exempted from the category “when,” that is, of time; for since God is the first mover, who moveth all things that are moved, and is moved by none, it followeth that He is not subject unto time, which is the number of motion by prior and posterior. And this agreeth well with the Scripture, which calleth God eternal, Genesis 21:33, the inhabitant of eternity, Isaiah 57:15. But eternity is an infinite and indivisible act, whereby God is what He is, unchangeably forever. Three things are essential unto eternity:

I. That it lacketh beginning and end.

II. And that it is wholly continuous and present, 1 Timothy 6:16, without succession of parts past or future, and prior, Revelation 1:4, or posterior.

III. That what He is, He is unchangeably.

And this last is the foundation of both; for that which is changed hath a past and a future, and something prior, something posterior. And as motion leadeth unto change, and change unto generation and destruction, so contrariwise, immobility leadeth unto eternity.

Gomarus continueth: Eternity properly so called is infinite duration, or that which necessarily lacketh every term and change. Which attribute also belongeth unto God alone. For first, He alone necessarily lacketh both terms, both the beginning from which, and the end to which it tendeth. Hence God is from everlasting to everlasting, Psalm 90:2, the first and the last, Isaiah 44:6 and 48:12, and the only immortal, 1 Timothy 6:16, by excellence (as being from Himself and absolutely), He is celebrated. Then, He is immune from all succession and change, both in act and in potency, by Himself and from Himself. For He remaineth the same, Psalm 102:27-28, Hebrews 1:11-12, absolutely and from Himself incorruptible, 1 Timothy 1:17, with whom there is no shadow of change, James 1:17. Therefore, God is properly eternal, Romans 16:26, Isaiah 40:28, Genesis 21:33, 1 Timothy 1:17; but creatures are called eternal only unmeetly and metaphorically. For they both have a beginning from God and could have an end through God’s power; and they are subject unto many manners of succession and change. And therefore, albeit they be in themselves and in their own way eternal, yet in comparison with God, the fountain of essence and life, Psalm 36:9, they are neither eternal nor anything, divinely considered, Isaiah 40:17. See Jerome, 102nd Epistle unto Damasus.

Walaeus addeth: But in eternity there be these twain things: that it lacketh beginning and end, then that it lacketh all succession and change, according unto that saying of Boethius: eternity is the complete and perfect possession of interminable life all at once; both of which are found in time.

Objection: But God is called autoōn, from Himself.

Response: That signifieth not affirmatively that He hath origin from Himself, when He was not yet; for this were contradictory; but it signifieth negatively that He hath origin from none, but is from Himself, and by Himself: that is, He is the first being, depending on no other, and self-sufficient.

Junius saith: But when we say that the Father or the Son is from Himself, we understand not that He is from Himself properly and absolutely, either by origin or by act, that they are produced by themselves and subsist by themselves; but figuratively by negation, that they are not produced nor subsist from any other.

Walaeus:

Question. Whether God’s eternity be without any change and succession, and is all at once?

Response. Vorstius expressly denieth this; yet all the Orthodox embrace the contrary, even the ancient Fathers and all the Scholastics. The arguments for that opinion be these:

Argument 1: It is taken from the places of Holy Scripture that attribute all differences of times unto God at once. As Psalm 102:27, cited also by the Apostle, Hebrews 1:11, “The heavens shall perish, but thou shalt endure, and they all shall wax old as doth a garment; and as a vesture shalt thou fold them up, and they shall be changed: but thou art the same, and thy years shall not fail.” Likewise, Hebrews 13:8, “Jesus Christ the same yesterday, and today, and forever.” And Revelation 1:8, “Which is, and which was, and which is to come.” Where all differences of times are attributed unto God at once, to show that they are one and the same in God; and therefore in Exodus 3:14, He is called Eheje, “I will be,” and Jehovah, “who is.” And Psalm 2:7, “Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee.” And 2 Peter 3:8, “One day is with the Lord as a thousand years.” Job 36:26, “The number of His years is unsearchable.” All which could not be truly spoken of God if there were succession and change of times in Him, as in creatures.

Argument 2: No succession of time falleth upon God; therefore, neither upon His eternity; since the eternity of God is an essential attribute of God, and therefore God Himself is eternal. Yea verily, the duration of every thing differeth not from the thing itself save in reason; for the duration of a thing is the thing with the negation of its destruction.

Argument 3: In every succession, there is a reduction from potency unto act, also from being unto not being, and from not being unto being. For past duration is no more, and future is not yet. But that something was in God that is no more, or something future that is not yet, is altogether alien unto God’s immutability, since God is the most perfect and simplest act.

Argument 4: It is taken from God’s immutable knowledge and other immanent actions, which are all eternal and individual, and lack succession of time; for if all things are present unto God’s knowledge from eternity, and that with one intuition, without any succession of past and future, then also all things are present unto His essence, for His knowledge is His essence. But that all things are present unto God’s knowledge and known from eternity, the Scripture expressly testifieth, Psalm 139:2, Acts 15:18, “Known unto God are all His works from the beginning of the world,” Hebrews 4:13.

Instance: But God is said to foreknow and foretell things.

Response: That is said with respect unto the things themselves, which are posterior unto the divine knowledge; albeit even in their time they coexist with the eternal knowledge of God.

Argument 5: The Scripture putteth for the same thing, that something was done from eternity, and that something was done before the foundation of the world, as was shown afore. Therefore, there is no succession of times in eternity before the created world; since before the created world there was not, therefore neither after the created world is there any succession in God’s eternity; since in God’s eternity, by the creation of things, nothing is detracted from God or from His perfection. Thus also the Angel sweareth, Revelation 10:6, that after the end of this world there shall be time no longer, and yet God in Himself shall not be changed.

Objection: If the past and the future coexist with eternity, therefore they also coexist with each other. For things that agree with one third thing also agree with each other.

Response: We deny the consequence, for they consist with eternity not confusedly, but in the order in which they exist. Even as the sun and its motion coexist with all the days of the age, yet it followeth not that they all coexist with each other; for each day coexisteth with the sun in its own order, which is alway the same. But in eternity, albeit all things are comprehended at once, yet they are not comprehended confusedly, but each in its own order: thus Adam and his sons and grandsons coexist with eternity, but each in his own order; the present coexisteth with eternity, the future also coexisteth with eternity, also the past coexisteth with the same, and all are comprehended at once in their order by eternity. Even as a small portion of water flowing in the midst of the sea is touched by the sea according unto all its parts, and is comprehended by it, and yet all the drops in that portion touch not each other.

Objection: Things will never arise nor perish, for they will alway be present unto eternity.

Response: With respect unto eternity, they arise not nor perish, for they arise not nor perish after eternity nor before eternity; but with respect unto their existence in time: thus Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob were dead in themselves, and yet they lived unto God, as Christ speaketh, Matthew 22:32.

Objection: The Scripture ascribeth differences of times unto God: as Revelation 1:4, “Which is, and which was, and which is to come.” And Daniel 7:9, He is called the Ancient of days. Psalm 102:28, “Thy years shall have no end.” Isaiah 44:6, “The first and the last.”

Response: These are accommodated unto our capacity of understanding, and from the thing itself, for which these are attributed unto God, it is evidently demonstrated that in God’s eternity there is no succession nor change, as was seen afore.

XVII. And the essence of God is immense, not confined nor excluded by any spaces of things or places.

Junius declareth: Immensity in God is an infinite act, whereby He is nowhere circumscriptively, but repletively in all things, and wholly everywhere through essence, and in the things themselves through presence and power, Psalm 139, Isaiah 66:1, Jeremiah 23:23. For God is both in all things and without all things: containing all things, and contained nowhere; even as it is said of the outermost sphere, whose space is everywhere, its circumference nowhere.

Gomarus saith: But the immensity of God is that whereby His individual essence cannot be bounded by any dimension of place, Psalm 145:3, Acts 17:27-28. “Do not I fill heaven and earth? saith the LORD,” Jeremiah 23:24; yet He cannot be included by them, 1 Kings 8:27, Psalm 139:7-10, Isaiah 66:1-2. Therefore, by the Jews, God is metonymically called Makom, that is, Place, for He is everywhere, yet no place can comprehend Him, Elias in Tishbi.

Walaeus addeth: Forasmuch as Vorstius in the explication of this divine attribute (as also elsewhere some Remonstrants) and among the Anabaptists a certain Cutper, Bishop of Harlem, think and speak very heterodoxly in their writings, therefore this also must be explained and asserted by us here a little more accurately. It is asked whether God be present unto all created things through His essence, or only through His power and might; but that the divine essence hath place only in some part of heaven? As Vorstius and Cutper dare to assert. All the Orthodox rightly contend that God is everywhere, through His essence, both in heaven and on earth, and condemn the contrary opinion as blasphemy. And this is proved by the arguments following:

Argument 1: There be very many places of Holy Scripture that clearly assert this. As Psalm 139:7-10, “Whither shall I go from Thy Spirit? or whither shall I flee from Thy presence? If I ascend up into heaven, Thou art there: if I make my bed in hell, behold, Thou art there. If I take the wings of the morning, and dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea; even there shall Thy hand lead me.” Isaiah 40:12, “Who hath measured the waters in the hollow of His hand, and meted out heaven with the span?” And verse 22, “It is He that sitteth upon the circle of the earth, and stretcheth out the heavens as a curtain.” And Isaiah 66:1, “Thus saith the LORD, The heaven is My throne, and the earth is My footstool: where is the house that ye build unto Me? and where is the place of My rest?” Likewise, Jeremiah 23:24, “Can any hide himself in secret places that I shall not see him? saith the LORD. Do not I fill heaven and earth?” From these places and the like, it is manifest that the very essence of God is present and efficacious everywhere.

Argument 2: If God created heaven and earth and all that is in them, being present, out of nothing, then He is present unto all creatures through His essence. The antecedent is agreed upon by all Christians; therefore, the consequent ought to be beyond controversy.

Argument 3: From the sustaining and governing of all created things; for in Him we live, and move, and have our being, Acts 17:28; Colossians 1:17, “And He is before all things, and by Him all things consist”; Hebrews 1:3, “Upholding all things by the word of His power,” and in many other places.

Argument 4: It is taken from the operation and indwelling of God in the hearts of all, Matthew 18:20, “Where two or three are gathered together in My name, there am I in the midst of them.” John 14:23, “If a man love Me, he will keep My words: and My Father will love him, and We will come unto him, and make Our abode with him.” Romans 8:16, 1 Corinthians 6:19, and so forth.

Argument 5: God beholdeth and searcheth the hearts of all men who are in the whole world; therefore, He is present unto them through His essence. The consequence is manifest, for all knowledge is through the conjunction of the known thing with the knowing intellect; which, since it can be done in twain ways, either through species abstracted from things, or through the conjunction of the knowing intellect with the very essence of things, the latter manner can only be thought of here; for what species would ascend from all men’s thoughts from the heart of men unto the highest heaven, unto the divine intellect? Since these be absurd, it followeth that the divine intellect penetrateth all things and searcheth all things through itself, and is present unto the hearts of men.

Argument 6: It is taken from the hypostatic union of the human nature of Christ with His deity, when He walked on earth. Unless they say that the divine nature of Christ deserted heaven when it was united with the human nature here; which introduceth a division of the divine essence, or that this union was made only through the operation of the divine nature upon the human; which is Nestorian, and condemned by the whole ancient church.

Objection: The Scripture itself in many places seemeth altogether to affirm that God, by reason of His substance, is only in heaven.

Response: Indeed, the Scripture saith that God is in heaven, but it never saith that He is only in heaven, and the contrary hath already been proved by evident places in Argument 1.

Objection 2: It is unworthy of God to be present in filthy places with His most pure essence; and the very majesty of God seemeth to require that He have His essence abstracted from these earthly and filthy things; for otherwise He seemeth to be mixed with those things and to become part of them.

Response: Why doth not the same seem concerning the Sun, Moon, and other stars, and the heavens? Secondly, the consequence is denied, for God’s essence is not mixed with things, nor is it defiled by filthy things, no more than the light of the Sun, or our soul with the filthy places of our body, which yet it sustaineth and ruleth. Then, if this were true, how was the essence of the Son of God hypostatically united with the flesh of Christ in the womb of the Virgin, or how do we live, move, and have our being in Him? And filthy places are oft changed into splendid ones, and splendid into filthy; doth God then also change place?

Objection 3: If God be infinite, where then is He outside the world, since there is no place there?

Response: Where was He before He created the world? Namely, in Himself. As Tertullian rightly taught against Praxeas: Before all things, God was alone, Himself unto Himself both place and world, and all things. Whence also the verse: Say where He was then, when there was nothing besides Him: Then, where He is now, in Himself, since He sufficeth unto Himself. This only difference can be given here, that before the creation of all things, God was in Himself through His essence and internal operations; but after things were created, through His essence, knowledge of Himself, and providence or operations also outwardly; and unto this agreeth the saying of Christ, John 14:10, “Believest thou not that I am in the Father, and the Father in Me?” And 1 Corinthians 2:11, “For what man knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit of man which is in him? even so the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God,” namely, which is in Him.

XVIII. Just as other attributes, so virtues are attributed unto God: goodness, holiness, justice, etc.

Ames saith: The affections which are attributed unto God in the Scripture, as love, hatred, and the like, either designate acts of will or agree with God only figuratively. Virtue is the perfection of the intellect and will, such as in God is wisdom, holiness, and the rest. Virtue is attributed unto God, whereby it denoteth readiness to act; not under the notion of a habit distinct from faculty and act. But the virtues which in man arise from the occasion of sin and imperfection agree not with God, as humility, chastity, shame, and the like.

Junius declareth: Good is essential unto God alone; but unto creatures it is accidental and by participation. Matthew 19:17, “There is none good but one, that is, God.” But whatsoever goodness is in created things, it is from Him, from whose fullness we draw all things. But God is good both efficiently, essentially, and finally. Efficiently indeed, since all things flow from Him; essentially, since He is perfectly good from Himself; finally, since all things are referred unto Him, from whom and for whom are all things. And for this cause, God is the utmost end to which all things tend; and the chief good, both unto Himself and unto all outside Himself.

The Professor affirmeth: The affections of good (which in men be passions) and the virtues, both of the intellect and of the will, which in them be ethical and moral habits, and designate the moderation of affections, such as truth, love, goodness, kindness, charity, beneficence, mercy, long-suffering, anger, hatred, justice, and finally holiness, etc., are truly and properly said of God, with all imperfection removed, and they be nothing else than the ardent will of God toward us, and in creatures His power and effect, whereby, according unto the diversity of objects and manners of acting, and sundry effects, they receive diverse names. Therefore, truth or veracity is that whereby God, both in words, in signs, and in works and deeds, loveth and employeth truth, but especially in promises He willeth and can keep faith, Psalm 145:13, Romans 3:4. Goodness, whereby He can and willeth and doth good unto creatures, Exodus 33:19, Romans 2:4. Love, whereby He willeth and approveth the good in creatures, and resteth in it, and willeth and can and doth show Himself unduly kind and gracious, which, when referred unto man, is called philanthropy, Malachi 1:2-3, Titus 3:4. Mercy and compassion, whereby He willeth and can and doth succour the miserable, Psalm 136:1, Exodus 34:5-7. Justice, whereby He disposeth all things justly, and decreeth rewards for the just, punishments for the unjust, and willeth and powerfully doth recompense, Psalm 11:7, Psalm 119:137, and 145:17. Anger, whereby He is inclined to punish the sinner, and willeth and can and doth avenge sin. Hatred, whereby He abhorreth sin and the sinner, and can and willeth constantly to reject the wicked from Himself. Finally, holiness, whereby, being most pure in Himself, He approveth all purity and abhorreth the contrary. Whence God is called in the Scripture truthful, good, kind, judge of the whole world, and just judge, etc., yea, the only truthful, good, holy, Revelation 15:4, Romans 3:4, Matthew 19:17, etc., and so of the rest, and He is the fountain of all truth, goodness, justice, and holiness. Furthermore, as these be truly attributed unto God, so the vices contrary unto these virtues are removed from God, as lying, injustice, and the rest, Numbers 23:19, 2 Chronicles 19:7, Romans 9:14. Whence He is also called “who cannot lie,” and “untempted by evils,” who cannot be tempted by evils, and He is denied to be unjust, Titus 1:2, James 1:13, Romans 3:5. Also repentance, fear, sorrow, hope, and despair, and other such things fall not into the perfect nature of God, Numbers 23.

Gomarus saith: But the holiness of God is His universal justice, or infinite and simple virtue of God, whereby He loveth Himself as the chief good and the fountain of all good, James 1:17, and other things consonant with His right reason and will, Psalm 33:5, and abhorreth things dissonant, Psalm 5:4-5, Habakkuk 1:13; whence He is called perfect, Matthew 5:48, Psalm 18:30, holy, holy, Isaiah 40:25, by excellence (since there is none holy as the LORD, 1 Samuel 2:2), the only holy, Revelation 15:4, the only good, Matthew 19:17 (as being from Himself most perfectly, and immutable in essence, and the fountain of holiness), He is named. But the holiness of creatures is an accident, which they have from God, and can be changed, and again, through the omnipotence of their giver, can be taken away. Therefore, compared with the infinite excellence of God’s holiness, it is not holiness, Isaiah 40:17, Job 25:5.

Walaeus continueth: Having expounded the divine properties that be attributed unto God by way of faculties, it followeth that we treat of those that be predicated of God by way of virtues or affections. But they can be referred either unto God’s goodness or unto His justice. For albeit justice can in some wise be referred unto goodness, yet sometimes in a stricter signification it is distinguished from it, yea, opposed unto it.

Maccovius saith: Grace is the favour of God toward the rational creature; but this grace of God is distinguished into grace absolutely so called, and grace called mercy. The grace that is called mercy is toward sinners, whom He promoteth unto salvation. But it is grace toward the miserable, or mercy, His most inclined will to succour the miserable, from which all benefits proceed, Exodus 34:6, Romans 9:18. Socinus denieth that mercy is an essential attribute of God; but he is mistaken; for the mercy of God is nothing else than the goodness of God, but who would be so impious as to establish that goodness is not essential unto God? But that the mercy of God is His goodness and kindness is evident, Titus 3:4, Romans 2:4 and 11:22, Ephesians 2:7, Titus 2:11.

Walaeus addeth: Of the same nature with grace and as it were a certain part of it is divine mercy, so called because the misery of another is to the heart. This is properly attributed unto God, not insofar as it signifieth sorrow conceived from another’s misery, but insofar as it signifieth a mind inclined to succour another’s misery; also the help itself. And not only anthropopathically, but properly, for that inclination had place in God from eternity, and for that we are commanded to be merciful after the example of God, Luke 6:36, “Be ye therefore merciful, as your Father also is merciful.” And therefore, He is called the Father of mercies. This mercy is twofold: either general, whereby He hath mercy on all creatures, Psalm 104:27, or special, whereby He hath mercy on His own; whence Romans 9:18, the Apostle saith, “He hath mercy on whom He will have mercy,” and God Himself, “I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy,” Exodus 33:19.

Question. It is here asked whether the justice that recompenseth punishment for sin be a natural property of God, which God cannot deny; or some indifferent thing, which God can admit or omit without harm unto His nature?

Response: We assert that this retributive justice or the wrath of God against sins is no less natural unto God than His holiness and goodness. The Socinians, with Vorstius, deny this, and say that the punishments of sin be free actions of the divine will, which God can exercise or not exercise without harm unto His nature. The cause of this assertion of theirs is to lay a foundation here for their profane doctrine, whereby they deny the true satisfaction of Christ for sins. And albeit here the will and decree of God, which required this satisfaction, could suffice for us, yet not even this should be conceded unto them, that this justice is not natural unto God. Therefore, let the arguments on both sides be weighed:

Argument 1: Whereby it is proved that vindictive justice, or hatred of sin, is natural unto God, is taken from the contrary, namely, from the love of justice and piety, which all confess to be proper and natural unto God. Whence it is evidently inferred that this vindictive justice is also natural unto God, or is to be referred among the divine properties.

Argument 2: The same is also proved by evident places of Scripture, as Psalm 5:4, “For Thou art not a God that hath pleasure in wickedness: neither shall evil dwell with Thee.” Likewise, Psalm 34:16, “The face of the LORD is against them that do evil.” Romans 1:18, “For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men.”

Argument 3: This is so properly attributed unto God in the Scripture that through vindictive justice He is distinguished from others, even from false gods, as Exodus 34:7, “That will by no means clear the guilty; visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, and upon the children’s children, unto the third and to the fourth generation.” Likewise, 2 Thessalonians 1:6, “Seeing it is a righteous thing with God to recompense tribulation to them that trouble you.” And Habakkuk 1:13, “Thou art of purer eyes than to behold evil, and canst not look on iniquity: wherefore lookest Thou upon them that deal treacherously, and holdest Thy tongue when the wicked devoureth the man that is more righteous than he?”

Argument 4: The law is the mirror of the divine nature, as to moral actions. Therefore, the sanction of the law is the mirror of the same divine nature in this part: namely, “Cursed is every one that continueth not in all things which are written in the book of the law to do them.”

Argument 5: Mercy is natural unto Him, as all confess. Therefore, also vindictive justice, for they be virtues of the same kind, though opposite. And all men by nature acknowledge that God is merciful toward those whom He spareth, and just toward those whom He punisheth.

Argument 6: It was necessary for our redemption that Christ should take upon Himself our sins. Therefore, the justice of God, which required this, is natural unto God. For wherefore would God have given His Son unto death for us if His justice had not required it? The antecedent is proved by evident places of Scripture, as Matthew 26:39, “O My Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from Me.” And Hebrews 2:10, “For it became Him, for whom are all things, and by whom are all things, in bringing many sons unto glory, to make the captain of their salvation perfect through sufferings.” And Hebrews 9:23, “It was therefore necessary that the patterns of things in the heavens should be purified with these; but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these.”

Objection: If this justice be natural unto God, then He will necessarily exercise it against all sinners, nor can He suspend punishment nor forgive sin.

Response: We deny the consequence, for the acts of all divine attributes are exercised by the divine will, according unto His wisdom, which also hath regard here unto other attributes, as the divine long-suffering, mercy, etc. But He forgiveth sins, yet transferred unto Christ our surety, as the Scripture speaketh, Isaiah 53:5 and 2 Corinthians 5:19.

Objection: But it is lawful for any to remit his right. Therefore, God also can do it.

Response: If this be true, then it followeth that God can also forgive the sins of the impenitent; for we not only can but also ought to forgive them. Then, indeed, we ought to forgive a private injury, but a public one a judge or lord ought not, except for the gravest causes. But God hath remitted His right to this extent, for He punished sins not in the persons themselves, but in their surety.

XIX. God is also of infinite power.

Walaeus saith: Power is distinguished from authority, for authority in Greek is exousia, denoting rather the right and power of acting; but power is dynamis, that is, efficacy and strength.

Maccovius addeth: The authority of God is the right and dominion of God over creatures, to do with them as He pleaseth. Concerning this, these things are asked:

I. On what doth it rest?

II. How far doth it extend?

III. By what justice can its effects and actions be called just?

The authority of God over the creature resteth on the superiority of the divine essence. There be those who say that God’s dominion over His creatures resteth on the benefits that He hath conferred upon them; and therefore, He hath as much right over His creatures as are His benefits; wherefore, since the benefits conferred by God upon the creature be not infinite (since no creature is capable of the infinite), therefore neither is God’s dominion over the creature infinite and altogether absolute, and thus there interveneth the law that God hath given unto man, according unto which He dealeth with him, not exceeding His benefits. But this opinion conflicteth with Scripture and reason. And first indeed with Scripture. For if God had no more right over the creature than the extent of His benefits upon it, it would follow that God useth not gratuitous goodness toward the creature when He benefiteth it according unto the law, but that this hath the nature of justice; but contrariwise, the Scripture testifieth that God, even when He rewardeth those who have fulfilled the law, useth gratuitous goodness in this part, which is clear from the second commandment of the Decalogue, “Shewing mercy unto thousands.” And Christ, “When ye shall have done all those things which are commanded you, say, We are unprofitable servants,” Luke 17:10. Why unprofitable? For we have done nothing but what we ought. And it must be observed that Christ commandeth us then to acknowledge ourselves servants; for the right of a lord over a servant resteth not on the benefits that the servant hath received from the lord, but on superiority; thus, God’s dominion over man resteth not on the benefits that man hath received from Him. Secondly, that opinion conflicteth with reason. For even the right that we have over other men resteth not alway on the benefits they have received from us, such as the dominion we have over servants; on what, therefore, doth it rest? Namely, on the excellence of superiority. Whence also Aristotle teacheth that if there were one who surpassed all other men in wisdom, he would be worthy to whom all mortals would defer authority. Therefore, God, because of the superiority of dignity and excellence, of which there is no proportion betwixt Him and the creature, hath the most absolute and infinite dominion over the creature. This authority of God extendeth unto sundry things, and hath or can have effects that human reason, if it be without the word of God, would easily reject as unjust. Therefore, all these be just, for what God doeth, those works be beyond all doubt just. Which Piscator calleth justice founded on the absolute authority of God; Twissus in his Vindiciae, book 1, part 2, page 156, calleth it the justice of the Lord of life and death. Nor, saith he, doth every just action require a meritorious cause, but only the just action of God as judge, not however the just action of God as Lord of life and death. God made us lords of life and death with respect unto inferior creatures, which therefore we treat at our pleasure unto killing and slaughter, and when we do this, we be not unjust, but just, albeit no demerit interveneth.

XX. Now, whatever God is, He is immutably.

Junius declareth: The last negative attribute is immutable, whereby God is exempted from the category of quality, and all motion is denied of Him, which can easily be proved by running through all the species of motion, James 1:17. But God is most immutable, both in Himself and in His works. In Himself indeed, since He is immovable, both by reason of His most simple and perfect essence, and by reason of place, for He is immense, and filleth all things. But in His works, since He hath decreed all things from eternity uniformly, and executeth them most exactly in their time, according unto the immutable counsel of His will.

Walaeus addeth: This attribute of God also must be asserted against Vorstius and the Anabaptists. A thing is said to be changed, according unto Aristotle, in the first book of Physics, in four ways:

1. According unto essence.

2. According unto quantity.

3. According unto quality.

4. According unto local motion.

Maccovius affirmeth: God is altogether and simply immutable. This property is evident from God’s eternity; for what is eternal remaineth alway the same. But further, we prove this by other reasons also. Let the second argument be: If God be mutable, He will be mutable either by reason of essence, or by reason of place, or by reason of accidents, or by reason of decree, by reason of knowledge. But He is not changed in any of these ways. Therefore: Not by reason of essence, since in this wise He would not alway be God, but sometime He would not be, which is absurd even to think. Not by reason of place, otherwise God would be moved from place unto place, which cannot befit Him who is infinite. Not by reason of accidents, since there is no accident in God, as hath been shown. Not by reason of decree or proposed will, since God changeth not what He hath once decreed from eternity, Isaiah 14:27 and 46:10. Not by reason of knowledge, since God cannot be deceived in knowledge, who is omniscient. Furthermore, we argue thus thirdly: That which is supremely perfect cannot be changed. For whatsoever is changed is changed either for the better, or for the worse, or into a state equal unto the former. But that which is supremely perfect cannot be changed for the worse; for if it had the power to become worse, it would not be supremely perfect, for something more perfect than it could be given. Nor can it be changed for the better, since neither in this wise is it supremely perfect, for that better into which it would be changed would be more perfect. Nor can it be changed into a state equal unto the former, so that it putteth off some good that it had afore, and taketh on only something that it had not afore, since in this wise, since it would alway be destitute of some good, it would not be most perfect. Fourthly, this reason also is valid to overthrow this error: for that which is changed is changed either by an external cause, or by some internal principle of motion, or by both. But God cannot be changed by any external cause, since He is the first efficient cause, sustaining and preserving all things that be in nature. Nor can He be changed by any internal principle of motion, since in this wise God would be composite, who is most simple, since there would needs be in Him mover and moved, also He would consist of passive potency, who is pure act. Therefore, God cannot be changed. The same is testified by the sacred letters, Psalm 102:27, “But Thou art the same, and Thy years shall have no end.” Malachi 3:6, “For I am the LORD, I change not.” James 1:17, “With whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning.”

Objection: The essence of God is changed; for God was made man, that is, the Son of God was made man, changed, therefore, with a new substantial perfection acquired.

Response: Active change most befitteth God, for He changeth all things by His power, but passive change least of all. For if He were changed, He would lack some perfection, and would needs acquire it anew, which is repugnant unto His infinite perfection; therefore, when we say that God was made man, it must be understood actively, not passively; not by receiving some perfection from human nature, but rather by communicating it unto human nature. For by uniting His divine subsistence unto human nature, He became not more perfect Himself, but made human nature more perfect. For albeit to be man be in itself some perfection, yet when added unto God, it increaseth not His perfection. For He alone is made more perfect who, lacking some perfection, acquireth it. But God lacketh no perfection, but containeth in Himself eminently all perfection of created things; wherefore, with any created perfection added, He becometh not more perfect. For which cause also the Scholastics teach that the world, taken together with God, is indeed more good and more perfect things, but not a greater and more perfect good than God Himself is. Nor also did any change follow from this, since God was made man actively, not passively, that is, not by passively receiving some perfection from human nature, but by actively conferring His divine perfection upon human nature, in such wise that the soul united unto the body actively perfecteth the body, but is not passively perfected by it; for change requireth the passive acquisition of some perfection. Therefore, just as the soul, by acting and perfecting the body, is not itself changed, but changeth the body, but the body, passively receiving perfection from the soul, is properly changed; so God, united by His subsistence unto human nature, is not changed, for He hath Himself in this union by way of an act perfecting, but human nature, passively receiving from the Word the perfection of subsisting, is changed.

Walaeus saith: To be made is said either by change or by conjunction with another thing. Thus, Genesis 2:7, Adam is said to be made a living soul. Likewise, 1 Corinthians 15:45, “The first man Adam was made a living soul; the last Adam was made a quickening spirit,” that is, united into one person; in which wise the Word was made flesh, and it is also necessarily taken: as it is expounded in Philippians 2:7, “Took upon Him the form of a servant,” and Hebrews 2:14, “Was made partaker of flesh and blood,” as the children, those who are given unto Him by the Father, who indeed bore flesh and blood, but were not changed into it; but their flesh was united with their souls into one person. But chiefly, the dispute with Vorstius and his disciples concerneth us, about the mutability of God’s internal actions, and especially of the divine counsel and divine will, which he oft willeth to vary and change in God according unto the occasion of external things; but we, with the Holy Scripture, assert that God is immutable in this part also. Our reasons be these:

I. From the place James 1:17, “Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and cometh down from the Father of lights, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning.” If there be no change in God, therefore neither in His counsel nor will.

II. From places where it is properly treated of the divine will and counsels, as Isaiah 46:10, “My counsel shall stand, and I will do all My pleasure.” Likewise, Malachi 3:6, “For I am the LORD, I change not; therefore ye sons of Jacob are not consumed.” In which place He asserteth that therefore they be not consumed, for God changeth not His promises and purpose toward them. Thus finally, Hebrews 6:17-18, “Wherein God, willing more abundantly to shew unto the heirs of promise the immutability of His counsel, confirmed it by an oath: that by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie, we might have a strong consolation.” These be certain and clear.

III. If God changeth His counsel, He changeth it either because of defect of power or because of defect of wisdom, for these be the only causes why men can change counsel. But neither falleth upon God; for no one can resist His will, Romans 9:19, nor can He be turned from accomplishing His thought, Job 42:2, and with whom did He take counsel that he should instruct Him, or teach Him the path of judgment, or teach Him knowledge, or show unto Him the way of understanding? Isaiah 40:14. There is no wisdom, nor understanding, nor counsel against the LORD, Proverbs 21:30.

IV. If God changed His counsel, He would change it either for the better or for the worse. Neither can be, for He is most wise and best. Therefore, He changeth not.

Trelcatius concludeth: Whatsoever change seemeth to be attributed unto God in the Scriptures is not in God, but in things; and therefore, repentance, when spoken of God, signifieth not affections in God, but the effects of God in men.

XXI. Finally, God is eternally blessed in and from Himself.

Gomarus saith: Therefore, He is called Shaddai, the all-sufficient and blessed, 1 Timothy 1:11 and 6:15, by excellence (namely, from Himself altogether, and with immutable constancy). But creatures be considered perfect and blessed only by the grace of God, according unto their measure, and with a mutable condition through God’s omnipotence.

XXII. That which pertaineth unto the exposition of the divine essence in the abstract: the catholic faith is that it is common unto the three Persons, that God is one, the Persons three: Father, and Son, and Holy Spirit.

Junius saith: The words that we use in expounding this mystery be more plain: person, homoousios, essence, unity; trinity.

Walaeus poseth the question: Whether it be lawful to use such words here, which be not found in the Scripture, since in this mystery it is not lawful to speak beyond the Scripture?

Response: Albeit some of them be not found in so many letters, yet the thing itself is found, and words equivalent unto them. Then, either those very words be in the Scriptures, or their derivatives and synonyms, as shall be seen hereafter. Finally, if it were not lawful to use such words expressing the sense and mind of the Scripture, it would not be lawful to expound the Scripture in preaching, nor to translate it into other tongues. But that those words or their derivatives and synonyms be found in the Scriptures will be clear from the demonstration following. The word “essence” is attributed unto God, Job 12:16, “With Him is strength and wisdom.” Likewise, Proverbs 8:14, “Counsel is Mine, and sound wisdom.” As also Isaiah 28:29, “Wonderful in counsel, and excellent in working.” Unto this also pertaineth the word Jehovah, and Eheje, Exodus 3:14, “I will be that I will be,” and Revelation 1:8, “Which is, and which was, and which is to come.” Finally, unto this pertaineth what God affirmeth of Himself, Isaiah 44:6, “I am the first, and I am the last; and beside Me there is no God.” The word “Person” is contained in the word Elohim, and in the Greek word hypostasis; and the thing itself is expounded of God in many places, as shall be seen hereafter. The word “Trinity”; by the numbering number, 1 John 5:7, “For there are three that bear record in heaven.” By the numbered number in many places: as in the baptism of Christ, Matthew 3:16, in our baptism, Matthew 28:19, and in many other places. The word “unity,” wheresoever God is called one, or Jehovah one: as Deuteronomy 6:4, 1 Corinthians 8:4. But conjointly, these be also found in the Scripture, 1 John 5:7. This only is to be noted here in passing, that in our tongue we use not the word “Drievuldicheyt” quite properly; for this properly signifieth triplicity, and is derived from the German word “drievuldigh.” But words be not alway to be used with respect unto their origin, but according unto received custom; as is seen in the word “nature,” which is used for any essence, albeit it be derived from “nascendo.”

Gomarus concludeth: The catholic faith is this (as Athanasius piously and gravely admonisheth), that we worship Unity in Trinity, and Trinity in Unity. The Greek word hypostasis is derived from hyphistēmi, to subsist. Damascene, Dialectica, chapter 26; Suidas, Lexicon. Not from stēkein tē ousia, that it standeth with the essence, as is wrongly taught in the Treatise of Definitions, which is most unworthily ascribed unto Athanasius, Tome 2. Abstractly, it properly signifieth the act of subsisting. Concretely, the subsisting thing. Generally, any substance or thing subsisting by itself, Damascene, First Institution, chapter 2, and Dialectica, 10, 25 (whether it underlieth accidents or underlieth not; whether it be living or lifeless, Treatise of Definitions, 1, 2, Athanasius), it signifieth. In which wise also unto fire, by Cyril of Alexandria, On the Trinity and Person of Christ, chapter 8, and unto a comet, and the like, by the Philosopher, On the World, chapter 4, its hypostasis is attributed. Wherefore, even if Socrates the historian, Ecclesiastical History, book 3, chapter 5, Greek 7, confesseth that more recent philosophers oft used the word hypostasis, yet he less rightly asserteth that it was passed over by the ancients. Concerning which general signification, either Jerome, Tome 2, Epistle to Damasus, the whole school of the seculars knoweth nothing else of hypostasis but ousia, and Athanasius, Epistle to the Africans, and Epistle to the Antiochians; hypostasis, ousia is, and signifieth nothing else than that very thing which is. Namely, if thou lookest at the use of the word outside the church, Theodoret, Dialogue 1, chapter 2, 8. Therefore, in the Council of Sardica (in which most were Westerners), one hypostasis of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit was asserted, Theodoret, Ecclesiastical History, book 2, chapter 8, that is, as they expound there, essence. Which Jerome, Tome 2, Epistle to Damasus, at the beginning, followed more sharply; as Augustine more gently, Tome 3, On the Trinity, book 5, chapter 8, 9. But specifically, hypostasisis distinguished from the common essence by synecdoche, Cyril, On the Trinity and Person of Christ, chapter 13, and it signifieth any proper individual of the essence, subsisting in itself (even brute or inanimate, ibid., chapter 8, Damascene, Dialogue, chapters 10, 11, 25, 26, 32, and First Institution, chapter 2, 47), Athanasius, Dialogue 3, On the Trinity, Cyril, Dialogue 1, On the Trinity, Theodoret, Dialogue1, chapter 2. In which wise it is also taken in the Council of Nicaea, Acts of the Council of Nicaea, part 2, chapters 12 & 21, and by Dionysius the Areopagite, On Divine Names, chapter 2, by Justin, Exposition of the Faith, and by most of the Latins; who, writing in Greek about this matter, were wont to say (as Augustine teacheth, Tome 3, On the Trinity, book 5, chapter 8) one ousia, three hypostases, one essence, three substances. In which wise also, by the word “substance,” taken synecdochically for the individual of substance, Hilary oft rendered the name hypostasis into Latin, in his book On Synods. But later, lest the ambiguity of the word (as Thomas Aquinas, Summa, part 1, question 29, article 2, ad 2, relateth) might be an occasion of error, they preferred to translate subsistentia rather than substantia for hypostasis. And by this distinction of the word hypostasis taken generally or specifically, in the Council of Alexandria, the president Athanasius, in the Synodal Epistle to the Antiochians, Gregory of Nazianzus, Oration 21 in Praise of Athanasius, piously, prudently, and happily settled the unworthy dispute and logomachy in the Church about this word (after the agreement of the parties in the thing itself had been explored and demonstrated). And of this special use of the word hypostasis, twain causes were given in the same council: the necessity of explaining dogmas (against the tricks of heretics playing with homonyms), and the poverty of words, Socrates, History, book 3, chapter 5, Greek 7. Which be most just and customary reasons for extending or innovating a word, Cicero, On Ends, book 3, and On Oratory, book 3. Since the abundance of things is almost infinite, and there is a poverty of names, Aristotle, On Sophistical Refutations, chapter 3. Simplicius aptly saith, in Aristotle’s Categories, Quality, “It is not right that the thing should perish together with the lack of names.” Wherefore, undeservedly, Irenaeus the grammarian judged the word hypostasis, Greek and proper, varied by the Greek theologians by a trope, to be barbarous, Socrates, History, book 3, chapter 5, Greek 7. And in this sense, in Job 22:30, the Hebrew word Kim (from Kum, to rise, to stand), that is, substance or subsistence, the LXX interpreters rightly expound as hypostasis. Nor otherwise doth Kimchi, in his Lexicon, take it than for person; and akin unto this is that Jekum, Genesis 7:4, denoteth an individual living substance, beyond controversy, Kimchi in Lexicon, and others. Unto these is added the authority of the Apostle, greater than all exception, when he saith that the Son of God the Father is the express image of His hypostasis, Hebrews 1:3, that is, of His subsistence or person; not, however, of the essence, as the interpreters Chrysostom, Theodoret, Theophilus, Oecumenius, Athanasius, Dialogue 1, On the Trinity, Damascene, Orthodox Faith, book 1, chapter 9, show the necessary diversity of type and archetype, of the produced and the producer; and the unity of the essence of the Son and the Father is solidly proved. Wherefore, from all these, it is clear that the word hypostasis is comprehended both in the thing itself and in use by the Holy Letters. Therefore, rashly, both aforetime and in our times, it was condemned by the Arians and Samosatenians.

The word “Person” is used for any intelligent hypostasis. Which came to pass because of the poverty of the Latin tongue and the necessity of a general word that correspondeth unto hypostasis and prosopon; so that the truth of the orthodox doctrine might be more distinctly expounded among the pious, and far in the future, the snares of heretics might be better exposed. Which is confirmed by the testimony of Gregory of Nazianzus, Oration 21 in Praise of Athanasius, and by the ingenuous confession of Augustine, Tome 3, On the Trinity, book 5, chapters 5, 7, chapters 3, 4, 5, 6. In which signification of Person, the most ancient of the Latin Fathers, Tertullian, Against Praxeas, chapters 11, 12, 13, 14, oft used it, and rightly shone as an example unto posterity. For (as Augustine saith) it was lawful, by the necessity of speaking and disputing, to say “person,” not because the Scripture saith it, but because the Scripture contradicteth it not, Tome 3, On the Trinity, book 7, chapter 4. Such is also the reason observed in the treatment of other sciences and arts, in which very many words, because of the abundance of things and the poverty of words, have been transferred from common use unto another, so that they might serve the necessary distinction of things and accurate doctrine. Therefore, for the sake of speaking (saith the same Augustine) about ineffable things, so that we might in some wise speak what we can in no wise express, it was said by our Greeks, one essence, three substances (that is, hypostases); but by the Latins, one essence or substance, three Persons, Tome 3, On the Trinity, book 7, chapter 4. Which word “Person” also many, with Augustine, Tome 3, On the Trinity, book 5, chapters 8 & 9, preferred unto others; for unto the Latins, substance is almost nothing else than essence; and unto the Greek fathers, hypostasis and prosopon generally signify the proper substance of each, animate or inanimate. Whence Damascene, Dialectica, chapter 26, and First Institution, chapter 1, saith, “The holy Fathers called hypostasis, individual, and prosopon the same,” Treatise of Definitions, Tome 2, Athanasius; Cyril, On the Trinity and Person, chapter 13; Athanasius, On the Trinity, Dialogue 1. But “Person” is taken only for an intelligent individual; whose definition, handed down by Philip Melanchthon, is more redundant and clear than that of Boethius and others: “A person is an individual substance, intelligent, incommunicable, not sustained in another nature.” Unto which Ursinus, as if adding the final touch, agreeth, when defining, he saith: “A subsisting individual, living, intelligent, incommunicable, not sustained in another, nor part of another,” in his Common Places on the Three Persons and in the Exposition of the Creed. Unto which definition, not undeservedly approved in the Schools, as we gladly assent, so also we sincerely, with the good will of the good and learned, contribute our symbol to illustrate the truth. For what if, rather, not negatively, what it is not, nor ambiguously (as we have just shown) with the word “incommunicable,” but affirmatively what it is, and with clear words (as the canons of definition prescribe, Aristotle, Topics, book 1, chapters 5, 6, chapter 2), we describe it in this wise? A person is a complete, singular, intelligent substance, proper, sustained in itself.

XXIII. The divine Persons are distinguished both among themselves and from the essence by a true distinction, but inexplicable unto us, and not to be expressed by any terms or notions except very imperfectly, according unto our manner.

Calvin admonisheth: Verily, here, if ever in the hidden mysteries of Scripture, we must philosophize soberly and with much moderation, also with much caution, lest either thought or tongue proceed beyond where the bounds of the word of God extend. For how shall the human mind define the immense essence of God according unto its own measure, which hath not yet been able to determine certainly what the body of the sun is, which yet is seen daily with the eyes? Yea verily, how shall it penetrate by its own guidance even unto the examination of the substance of God, which attaineth not unto its own? Therefore, let us willingly permit God the knowledge of Himself. For He alone, as Hilary saith, is a suitable witness unto Himself, who is not known except through Himself.

Junius continueth: Nor do they cease to be true hypostases because the one essence in number wholly subsisteth in each and all three Persons together the same, since for those three to be true subsistences, only these twain things are required: first, that they so truly subsist by themselves that one is not in another as an accident in a subject; then, that they be so distinct among themselves that one is not predicated of another; but that besides these twain, in created things, hypostases be divided from each other, that is to be attributed unto their finite condition; but the infinite essence, if it were divided according unto the Persons, would already cease to be infinite in fact; contrariwise, because it is infinite, one Person is in another, as Christ said, John 14, “I am in the Father, and the Father in Me”; which thing the Greek Fathers called enallēlon empeichōrēsis, the Scholastics mutual circumincession. Whence it is certainly established that the Persons be not divided from each other, but only distinct. And this distinction is either of the Persons with respect unto the essence, or of the Persons among themselves, or finally of the personal acts. The Persons from the essence, when compared only with the essence, differ only in reason; for a Person in God is nothing else than the divine essence itself, but in its characteristic property, and considered in the distinction of existence. But the Persons among themselves be distinguished not only in reason but in reality, in which real distinction be founded all those things of which we have spoken, properties, relations, characteristics, etc. This distinction is shown by very many places of Holy Scripture, Proverbs 8:24, John 5:18, 23, 26, Hebrews 1:3, John 5:26. First, those which testify unto the origin of the Son from the Father, and of the Holy Spirit from both; for the same cannot be produced by itself. Secondly, in which the Persons be called other from each other, as John 5, the Father is another witness from the Son; the Holy Spirit is another Paraclete from both, John 14. Finally, the forms of speaking where the Son is said to be with the Father, in the bosom of the Father, and the like. But how inept would these expressions be (if, as Sabellius once trifled) these were only diverse names of one thing?

Ames saith: The subsistences be distinguished from the essence as modes of subsisting, with the same concrete, from the same considered absolutely. Among themselves, they be distinguished as relatives, through certain relative properties; so that one cannot be another; yet they be at the same time nature; nor can they be called prior nor posterior, except in the order of origin and mode of subsisting.

Maresius addeth: Nor yet is a person properly composed of nature and supposit, for it is the function of a mode to modify, not to compose, and the supposit, as such, connoteth nature and essence, but modified.

XXIV. The Persons are distinguished among themselves by personal properties; as the Father, who is not a Person from another, begot the Son, and with the Son breatheth forth the Holy Spirit; the Son is begotten by the Father, and with Him breatheth forth the Holy Spirit; the Holy Spirit proceedeth from both.

Junius declareth: The personal acts (which be called ad intra) cannot be communicated unto other Persons any more than one Person can become another; such be the Father’s begetting and co-breathing; the Son’s being begotten and co-breathing; the Holy Spirit’s proceeding from both, as the Latins speak, or from the Father through the Son, as the Greeks; whence it followeth that these acts be not of a deliberating will, but of nature; for if they were of a deliberating will, they would not be ad intra, but ad extra; not proper unto the Persons, but common unto the essence; not of natural necessity, but of free power, from which it would follow that the Son and the Holy Spirit be creatures, and also could not be. But from both, it is also necessarily gathered that these acts be eternal and indefinite both in respect of principle and of end. For if they had an end, how was there not then something by which, having been produced, they began to have their perfection? How could that which hath an end not also have had a beginning? Finally, how was there not a change in God producing and ceasing to produce? Nor yet be these acts successive; for both eternity, which is all at once what it is, and the nature of the most simple thing, whose production is perfect in effect, but perpetual in effect, repugneth unto it; for if it had successive being, it would necessarily cease to be simple.

The Professor affirmeth: That the Person of the Father is truly a Person, and hath origin from no person, is agreed upon by all Christians; therefore, when He is said by some Orthodox to be from Himself, and autophyēs and autogennētos, that is to be understood negatively, not affirmatively, because namely He is from none, but from Himself; and through Himself, He subsisteth from all eternity.

Gomarus saith: The common mode is the communication of the divine essence (whence He is said to have given life unto the Son, John 5:26; and the Son is said to be in the form, that is, the nature of God, or homoousios and equal unto God, Philippians 2:6, unto the Father) and indeed not temporal, but eternal (for the essence of God is not changeable, Hebrews 1:10-12, James 1:17, and the going forth of the Son is from the days of eternity, Micah 5:2, Proverbs 8:22-23, 27), nor free (otherwise the Son would not be God, and the most necessary being), but natural; finally, He begot Him not outside Himself, but in Himself. For the Son so floweth from Him that He remaineth in Him. He floweth, otherwise the Father would not be Father; but He remaineth in Him; otherwise, the Father would not be God. For the essence of God can neither be separated nor divided, for it is most simple; therefore, both the Father is in the Son, and the Son in the Father, John 10:38 and 14:10, and one with Him, John 10:30, by the unity and community of essence, He is simply established.

But the Spirit proceedeth not by generation, for He Himself is nowhere said in the Holy Letters to be begotten; nor can He be said to be, for the Son is defined as the only begotten, John 1:14; but by spiration, for relatively, He is called the Spirit of God, Isaiah 61:1, and by a more express metaphor unto our capacity, the Spirit of the mouth of God, Psalm 33:6 (that is, who is as it were breathed from the mouth of God), He is named.

Walaeus concludeth: Concerning the Holy Spirit, it must be held that He proceedeth not only from the Father but also from the Son; or as the ancient Greek Fathers speak, that He proceedeth from the Father through the Son. Against the error of the Greeks of today; who indeed confess that the Holy Spirit proceedeth from the Father, but not from the Son, for it is written in John 15:26, “The Spirit of truth, which proceedeth from the Father.” But this manner of speaking is not to be understood exclusively; which the arguments following prove:

I. For in the Scripture, the Holy Spirit is no less called the Spirit of Christ than the Spirit of the Father, as in Romans 8:9, Paul calleth Him the Spirit of Christ, when he saith, “If any man have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of His.” And in verse 11 following, he calleth Him the Spirit of the Father, when he calleth Him the Spirit of Him that raised up Jesus from the dead. Likewise, Galatians 4:6, “And because ye are sons, God hath sent forth the Spirit of His Son into your hearts.”

II. For the Holy Spirit is no less sent by the Son than by the Father. As Christ Himself testifieth, John 15:26, “But when the Comforter is come, whom I will send unto you from the Father, even the Spirit of truth, which proceedeth from the Father, He shall testify of Me.” And John 16:7, “Nevertheless I tell you the truth; It is expedient for you that I go away: for if I go not away, the Comforter will not come unto you; but if I depart, I will send Him unto you.” Finally, Christ Himself testifieth, John 16:15, “All things that the Father hath are Mine: therefore said I, that He shall take of Mine, and shall shew it unto you.”

XXV. But the Trinity of Persons in God is proved from the Scriptures by arguments both general, which teach it, and special, concerning the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit separately.

Walaeus affirmeth: That there be not only one Person in God, but more, is demonstrated by evident places of Holy Scripture, both of the Old and New Testament.

Reason 1: It is taken from the plural form of the words Elohim, Adonai, which be everywhere spoken of God in the Scriptures; and especially when a plural verb is joined with them, as Genesis 20:13, “When God caused me to wander from my father’s house.” And Genesis 35:7, “Because there God revealed Himself unto him.” Likewise, Deuteronomy 5:26, “For who is there of all flesh, that hath heard the voice of the living God?” Other like places also occur everywhere concerning God, when those twain words be not joined, as Isaiah 49:2, “Thus saith the LORD that made thee.” Likewise, Psalm 149:2, also Isaiah 54:5, “Thy Maker is thine Husband.”

Reason 2: From places where God Himself speaketh of Himself in the plural number, Genesis 1:26, “Let Us make man in Our image.” And Genesis 3:22, “Behold, the man is become as one of Us.” And Genesis 11:7, God said, “Let Us go down, and there confound their language.” Likewise, Isaiah 6:8, “I heard the voice of the Lord, saying, Whom shall I send, and who will go for Us?”

Reason 3: The same mystery is gathered from places where God speaketh of God as of another Person, as Genesis 19:24, “Then the LORD rained upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah brimstone and fire from the LORD out of heaven.” Exodus 34:5, “And the LORD descended in the cloud, and stood with him there, and proclaimed the name of the LORD.” Thus, that Trisagion, Isaiah 6, is expounded in the New Testament concerning all three Persons. See John 12:41, “These things said Esaias, when he saw His glory, and spake of Him.” Likewise, Acts 28:25, Paul saith, “Well spake the Holy Ghost by Esaias the prophet unto our fathers, saying, Go unto this people,” etc. And Daniel 9:17, “Hear, O Lord, for the Lord’s sake.”

That the plurality of Persons is terminated in the number of the Trinity, infinite places of Holy Scripture prove, especially the form of baptism which Christ prescribed, Matthew 28:19, “Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.” Therefore, the Father is the first Person, from whom the others have their origin, and who hath His origin from no other. Therefore, He is oft called Jehovah in the Old Testament; and in the New, God; for namely, not only with respect unto essence, but also with respect unto Person, He is from Himself, and for that He is as it were the fountain and origin of the whole deity. In the Old Testament, I remember not Him being expressly called Father, except in 2 Samuel 7:14, where concerning the Son, He is called Father, as the Apostle explaineth, Hebrews 1:5, “I will be to Him a Father, and He shall be to Me a Son.” And by evident consequence, Psalm 2:7, “Thou art My Son; this day have I begotten Thee,” as the Scripture itself explaineth, Hebrews 1:5 and 5:5, also Acts 4:25 and 13:32. Likewise, Proverbs 30:4, “Who hath established all the ends of the earth? what is His name, and what is His Son’s name?”

That the word “Son” is also spoken of the second Person in the Old Testament is clear from the places cited afore; but more oft in the Old Testament, He is indicated by other names: as the Word of God, the Angel of Jehovah, and the Angel of His face, also the wisdom of God; just as in the New also sometimes, especially in the Apocalypse, He is called by the name of the Angel of Jehovah; for He is sent by the Father for the salvation of men. Likewise, Logos, John 1:1, also the only begotten Son, also the firstborn, etc., in places to be adduced hereafter.

The Holy Spirit in the Old Testament also is called the Spirit of the Lord, and the Spirit of God, Genesis 1:2, also the Spirit of the Most High, Job 33:4, also the Spirit of holiness of God, Isaiah 63:10, and in the New more frequently the Holy Spirit, and the Spirit of truth, also the power of the Most High, Luke 1:35.

The places that treat of the Holy Trinity conjointly in the Old Testament be almost the following, namely, Genesis 1:4, “And God said, Let there be light: and there was light,” etc., and “The Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters.” “Said,” namely, in the Son, or through the Son, as John testifieth, chapter 1:3. But that the Spirit of the Lord here cannot be taken for a created breath or wind is clear from its effect; and for that the expanse was not yet created on the first day; in which the wind hath its place only. Another place in which there is a conjoint mention of the Trinity is 2 Samuel 23:2, “The Spirit of the LORD spake by me, and His word was in my tongue.” Likewise, Psalm 33:6, “By the word of the LORD were the heavens made; and all the host of them by the breath of His mouth.” Which places be indeed very probable; but for that they be called into doubt by some of ours, when we have to do with obstinate adversaries, it is better to urge the following from the Old Testament. Namely, the place from Psalm 45:6-7, “Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever: the sceptre of Thy kingdom is a right sceptre. Thou lovest righteousness, and hatest wickedness: therefore God, Thy God, hath anointed Thee with the oil of gladness above Thy fellows.” Which place is expounded concerning Christ Himself, as the Son of God, by the Apostle, Hebrews 1:8-9, “But unto the Son He saith, Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever,” etc. And accordingly also concerning the Holy Spirit, whom He received without measure. The second place is Psalm 110:1, “The LORD said unto my Lord.” And indeed, David said this concerning Christ, through the Spirit of the Lord, as Christ Himself testifieth, Matthew 22:43-44, “How then doth David in spirit call Him Lord, saying, The LORD said unto my Lord?” The third place is Isaiah 61:1, “The Spirit of the Lord GOD is upon me; because the LORD hath anointed me to preach good tidings unto the meek.” Where God the Father is understood by Him who anointed; the Son, by Him who was anointed; and the Spirit, by Him who was upon Him, as the Scripture itself also explaineth. But the firmest and clearest places of the Old Testament be the place Isaiah 63:7 and Haggai 2:5, if all the circumstances be weighed and compared with other places. But the place Isaiah 63:7-10 hath thus, “I will mention the lovingkindnesses of the LORD,” etc. “He said, Surely they are My people, in all their affliction He was afflicted, but the Angel of His presence saved them, in His love and in His pity He redeemed them, and He bare them, and carried them all the days of old. But they rebelled, and vexed His holy Spirit: therefore He was turned to be their enemy, and He fought against them.” Haggai 2:4-5 soundeth thus, “Yet now be strong, O Zerubbabel, saith the LORD; and be strong, O Joshua, son of Josedech, the high priest; and be strong, all ye people of the land, saith the LORD of hosts: for I am with you, saith the LORD of hosts: according to the word that I covenanted with you when ye came out of Egypt, so My Spirit remaineth among you.”

Thus far, the places of the Old Testament that treat of this mystery of the Trinity in general have been expounded; it followeth that we also adduce some from the New Testament, in which there is a conjoint mention of the three Persons. The first place is in the history of the baptism of Christ, Matthew 3:16-17, where Christ, according unto His human nature, is baptized by John the Baptist, and the Spirit of God descended like a dove, and came upon Him, and a voice from heaven from the Father descended, which said, “This is My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased: hear ye Him.” Another clear place of the New Testament in which the mystery of the Trinity is set forth is the place Matthew 28:19, “Baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.” The third place is John 15:26, in the promise of the Holy Spirit, where Christ saith, “But when the Comforter is come, whom I will send unto you from the Father, even the Spirit of truth, which proceedeth from the Father, He shall testify of Me.” And John 16:13, “When He, the Spirit of truth, is come, He will guide you into all truth: for He shall not speak of Himself; but whatsoever He shall hear, that shall He speak: and He will shew you things to come.” As also in John 14:26, He had said, “He shall teach you all things, and bring all things to your remembrance, whatsoever I have said unto you.” The fourth place is taken by us from 1 Corinthians 12:4-6, “Now there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit. And there are differences of administrations, but the same Lord.
