And there are diversities of operations, but it is the same God which worketh all in all.” And verse 11, that we may understand that he speaketh of the very Person of the Holy Spirit, he addeth, “But all these worketh that one and the selfsame Spirit, dividing to every man severally as He will.” Likewise, 2 Corinthians 13:14, these three be joined, when he closeth the epistle thus, “The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communion of the Holy Ghost, be with you all.” Likewise, a notable place is in 1 John 5:7, “For there are three that bear record in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost: and these three are one.” And finally, that manifest place, Revelation 1:4-5, “Grace be unto you, and peace, from Him which is, and which was, and which is to come; and from the seven Spirits which are before His throne; and from Jesus Christ, who is the faithful witness, and the first begotten of the dead, and the prince of the kings of the earth,” and many like ones.

Junius saith: Concerning the Son, we show this from the proper names by which the Person of the Son is distinguished in Holy Scripture, belonging only unto Him who is truly God; as, for example:

I. That He is called Son in the Scripture; not by institution, as the elect, etc., be called sons, but by nature; but that He is called Son by nature is proved from this, that He is not called Son absolutely, but His own, Romans 8:32. But His own Son is He who is by nature; but he who is by institution is called Son only figuratively.

II. He is called the only begotten, John 1:18. But if He were Son by institution, He would neither be begotten, except equivocally, nor the only begotten in any wise.

III. He is called the firstborn of every creature, Colossians 1:15, therefore begotten afore time began to flow in eternity; but from eternity, there was no son by institution. Nor doth it hinder if thou sayest “firstborn” figuratively, for Him who holdeth the first place in all creatures; for the Father hath bestowed this honour on no one but the only begotten Son, Hebrews 1:5.

Gomarus continueth: But that the Holy Spirit is a Person of the Deity, or truly God, no less than the Father and the Son, is confirmed by the demonstration of the Holy Letters, both by affirmation and by invincible reasons, through necessary consequence. For the affirmation of this is, first, in the Old Testament; both by itself and compared with the New. By itself, for that Jehovah whom the Israelites tempted in the wilderness, Numbers 14:22, Deuteronomy 6:16 and 9:7, is the same Holy Spirit, Isaiah 63:10, as is also asserted, Hebrews 3:7-9. Then, the Spirit of Jehovah, 2 Samuel 23:2, is the same as the God of Israel, verse 3. But if thou comparest it with the New Testament, Jehovah, who gave the law concerning the entrance of the sanctuary, Leviticus 16:2, is also the same Holy Spirit, Hebrews 9:7-8. Secondly, Jehovah, who spake in Isaiah 6:9, is also the same Holy Spirit, Acts 28:25. Finally, Jehovah, who promiseth us a new covenant, Jeremiah 31:31, is the Holy Spirit, Hebrews 10:15-16. But in the New Testament likewise, the Holy Spirit, Acts 5:3, is defined as God, verse 4, and 1 Corinthians 3:16-17. In which places, such circumstances be added that it appeareth that the word “God” is to be taken only of the true and eternal God. This concerning affirmation. But the sum of the reasons (by which the same is demonstrated in the sacred letters by the necessity of consequence) is that those things which be proper unto God alone, both internal and external, be divinely attributed unto the Holy Spirit. The internal be the essential properties of God: and first, eternity, for He preceded creation, Genesis 1:2, Psalm 95:5 with Hebrews 3:7-9. Then, immensity, for He is everywhere, and is not bounded by any spaces of places, Psalm 139:7, Romans 8:9, and 1 Corinthians 3:16, and 2 Timothy 1:14. Thirdly, omniscience, for He is infinitely wise. For the Spirit searcheth all things, yea, the deep things of God, 1 Corinthians 2:10, that is, by a metonymy usual of God, Romans 8:27, Revelation 2:23, He knoweth intimately, as the next words attest; for what man knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit of man which is in him? even so the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God, 1 Corinthians 2:11, namely, which is in Him; as the comparison argueth; and Cyril, in John, book 1, chapter 4, Thesaurus, book 13, chapter 1, oft supplieth. Finally, omnipotence, for the great God Jehovah, and the great King above all gods, Psalm 95:3, is the Holy Spirit, Hebrews 3:7-9. Then, for He worketh all things in all, as He willeth, 1 Corinthians 12:6 with 11. Whence also in the omnipotent work of the conception of Christ, He is called the power of the Highest, Luke 1:35, hypostatically; for in Him resideth the power of the Father (who is called the Most High in opposition unto creatures), and through Him it is exercised and manifested. And these concerning the internal properties of God, which belong unto the Holy Spirit. But the external properties of God, which be also ascribed unto the Holy Spirit in the sacred letters, be first, the works of God alone; then, religious and divine worship. But the works be partly of omniscience, partly of omnipotence. A work of omniscience is especially prophecy, and therefore proper unto God, Isaiah 41:22-23 and 46:9-10 and 48:5, whose entire inspiration is attributed unto the Holy Spirit, John 16:13 and 1 Peter 1:11, 2 Peter 1:21. But the works of omnipotence also belong unto Him; and first, universal: as the creation of the world. For Jehovah who made the sea, and whose hands formed the dry land, Psalm 95:5, is the Holy Spirit, Hebrews 3:9, 7, unto which agree Psalm 33:6 and Psalm 104:30, Job 26:13 and 33:4. Then, particular, and first, miracles, exceeding the powers of all creatures, which He effecteth by His power, 1 Corinthians 12:9-10. Such especially be the resurrection of the dead, Romans 8:11, then divine and saving benefits in the Church (whence He is also called the good Spirit, Psalm 143:10, and the bountiful or liberal Spirit, Psalm 51:12), partly ordinary, partly extraordinary. Ordinary, as regeneration, John 3:5 and 2 Corinthians 3:18, Titus 3:5, or the sanctification of the soul, 1 Corinthians 6:11 and 1 Peter 1:22, the giving of a new heart, Ezekiel 36:26-27, Ephesians 3:16, or of faith, 2 Corinthians 4:13, of hope, Romans 15:13, of charity, 2 Timothy 1:7, and of righteousness, Romans 14:17. Whence the Spirit of God, not only by nature but also by operation, is called the Holy Spirit, for a special reason (for the Father and the Son sanctify us through Him); for albeit each be absolutely spirit and holy, yet He is never called the Holy Spirit relatively or conjointly. But extraordinary, as the immediate leading of the Apostles into all truth, John 16:13, Acts 2:4, and the distribution of sundry charisms, which flow only from God’s omnipotence, be attributed unto the Holy Spirit as author, 1 Corinthians 12:9-11. And these concerning the first external properties of God, namely, works. The other is religious and divine worship; which (no less than divine works) is divinely attributed unto the Holy Spirit; and the first is His religious adoration. For it is rendered unto Him both by Angels, Isaiah 6:3 with Acts 28:25, and is also commanded unto the Church, Psalm 95:6, “O come, let us worship and bow down: let us kneel before the LORD our maker.” For here also is the Holy Spirit, verse 9, as the Apostle testifieth, Hebrews 3:7-9. Secondly, there be examples of religious and holy invocation in the Apostles: in Paul indeed, 2 Corinthians 13:14, “The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communion of the Holy Ghost, be with you all.” In John, Revelation 1:4, “Grace be unto you, and peace, from Him which is, and which was, and which is to come; and from the seven Spirits which are before His throne.” Thirdly, the faithful be called His temples; which be consecrated unto God alone, 1 Corinthians 3:16-17 and 6:19. See Augustine, Against Maximus, book 1, last chapter. Fourthly, in baptism, we be religiously bound unto His name and deity, no less than unto the Father and the Son, Matthew 28:19. Finally, He also maketh faith unto the rendering of divine worship, by that dreadful threatening against the violation of His worship and blasphemy against Him, that it shall never be forgiven, Mark 3:29, Hebrews 6:4 and 10:26, 29. From all which it is clear that since God willeth not to give the glory of His name unto another, for He is true, Isaiah 48:11, nor can He give it, for He is just, and jealous for the glory of His name, Deuteronomy 32:4 and Exodus 20:5, 7, and He hath given that glory unto the Holy Spirit, by affirming that He is God and Jehovah; and by ascribing unto Him the properties of God (both internal, or essential properties, and external; purely divine works, and religious and divine worship), therefore, by invincible consequence, we conclude that the Holy Spirit is true God.

Maccovius proceedeth: But let us proceed and prove that the Holy Spirit is not only a substance but also a Person. But we prove this by these arguments:

I. That the Scripture attributeth unto the Holy Spirit those things that belong only unto a Person. For:

I. A peculiar existence is attributed unto Him, for the Scripture, speaking everywhere of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, noteth three distinct subsistences, and attributeth unto each such things as belong only unto a true subsistence and unto a thing subsisting by itself.

II. Life is attributed unto Him, and that both subjectively (for otherwise, in the first production of all things out of nothing, He could not have brooded upon the waters, Genesis 1:2), and effectively, for He is the author of life, both animal, Job 33:4, and spiritual, John 3:5, Romans 8:2.

III. Omniscience and intelligence be attributed unto Him, for He is said to search the deep things of God, 1 Corinthians 2:10.

IV. Will, for He distributeth gifts as He willeth, 1 Corinthians 12:11.

V. Power, Isaiah 11:2. And other things of this kind, from which it necessarily followeth that the Holy Spirit is a true subsistence and a true Person subsisting in the divine essence.

II. Likewise, the personality of the Holy Spirit is not obscurely proved by the administration of our baptism, which is performed no less in the name, command, and authority of the Holy Spirit than in the name of the Father and of the Son; for expressly in this very work, He is numbered with the other Persons, Matthew 28:19. Therefore, since it is not said of things that be not Persons that something is done in their name, hence it altogether followeth that the Holy Spirit is a Person distinct from the Father and the Son.

III. Finally, the same personality of the Holy Spirit is also proved from His actions, which be everywhere attributed unto Him. For unto the Holy Spirit be attributed in the Scriptures such works and effects as belong only unto a Person. For He is said to teach and suggest, Matthew 10:20, Luke 12:12, John 14:26, to lead into all truth, John 16:13, to testify of Christ, John 15:26, to give and confer the word of wisdom, of knowledge, faith, prophecy, and kinds of tongues, 1 Corinthians 12:8, to comfort, John 14:16, to reprove the world of sin, John 16:8, to lead believers, Romans 8:14, to seal the faithful, Ephesians 4:30, to announce, speak, and foretell things to come, John 16:13, that He commandeth something to be done for Him, Acts 13:2.

XXVI. The Son and the Holy Spirit, although they be Persons from another, yet have the same common essence with the Father, which is from itself, and therefore be rightly called autotheos.

Zanchi saith: Whence we also understand how it is that, since the Son is no less omnipotent than the Father, and so also the Holy Spirit, yet we say not that they be three omnipotents, but only one omnipotent, as we confess with Athanasius in the Creed, and with the whole Church; for namely, there is only one and the same of all.

Trelcatius addeth: The Son, the second Person, by reason of Person existing from the Father by eternal generation (whose truth is hyperphysical, so also its mode is ineffable), but as to the absolute essence, He is from Himself, and autoōs. The Holy Spirit, the third, proceeding and emanating from the Father and the Son coeternally, by reason of His Person, Psalm 2:7, but by reason of essence, God from Himself, with the Father and the Son. It is one thing to speak of the origin of the essence, which in divine things there is none; another of the origin of the Persons. The Son and the Holy Spirit have origin only of Persons; the former by generation, the latter by procession eternal, neither of essence.

Gomarus affirmeth: Whosoever is God Himself, and truly, properly, and essentially God, He is autotheos. But the Son of God is God Himself, truly, properly, and essentially God. Therefore, He is autotheos. The proposition is confirmed both by the signification and by the use of the word autotheos among those Fathers from whom it originateth. Unto which also pertaineth that of Justin Martyr, the most ancient theologian, who in his Exhortation to the Greeks, page 13, Edition Commelinian, expounding theos autos, saith that the pronoun signifieth “Him who truly is God.” The assumption is true and certain, whence also the conclusion is true. Secondly, whosoever is autousia, autozōē, autoagios, autodynamis, autoagathotēs, autophōs, autoalētheia, autodikaiosynē, autosophia, autoteleios, autodoxa, he is also autotheos, for deity, His essence, and attributes be reciprocal; but the Son is such, as is clear from the right interpretation and use of those words from above, and from the nature of the Son described in the Holy Letters, 1 John 5:20; therefore, He is autotheos. Just as also the Fathers rightly assert. And this is so clear and certain that among the Papists, Bellarmine openly acknowledged it, and defended Calvin, against whom he is yet most oft unjust, in that matter against his Genebrard, book 2 On Christ, chapter 19. But someone may say, it is rightly said that the Son is autotheos in this sense, which agreeth with antiquity and the use of the word, but Bellarmine reproveth the manner of speaking, that Calvin saith the Son is autotheos, that is, God from Himself. Finally, that it is said unmeetly and harshly in the Creed: God from God, light from light. But contrariwise, Bellarmine cavilleth ineptly; for “from Himself” something is said to be in twain ways, either positively to be effected from Himself, or negatively to be without cause or not to be effected from another. In the former wise, it can belong neither unto deity nor unto any thing, for it implieth a contradiction, that it is its own cause and effect. But in the latter wise, it most excellently, yea necessarily, squareth with deity, for deity is the first being, without cause, and the cause of all beings, as the name Jehovah proveth, and the nature of God, Exodus 3, Revelation 1, and roundly Anastasius, and Cyril in the compendious exposition of the faith. What is God? Essence without cause, cause of all beings. And Gregory of Nazianzus, Oration 2 On the Son, “The cause of beings; deity.” For no one could say the cause of God. Thus, in the same place, when he calleth the Father the cause of the Son, yet he calleth the deity without cause. Why may it not be lawful to say, with the meaning rightly expounded, that the Son hath essence from Himself, not insofar as the word “from” denoteth only the term, for thus He hath from the Father by eternal communication of generation; nor insofar as “from Himself” denoteth positively effected from Himself, but insofar as taken negatively it removeth efficiency, and denoteth without cause, or not effected from any, against the opinion of Valentinus Gentilis, who confessed that the Son hath essence from the Father, but effected, that He was essentialized by the Father; unto which opinion Calvin contradicted, and in this wise Damascene speaketh, Orthodox Faith, book 1, chapter 8, when he commonly calleth God autousian, as not having being from another, that is, effectively, not however communicatively. For this doth not infringe autousian, but most confirmeth it.

Maccovius poseth:

Objection: John 17:3.

Response: In no wise doth the place of John favour the adversary, for first, Christ saith not in this place what the adversary willeth, that only the Father is the true God; but that the Father is that only true God; or is that God who alone is the true God; it is manifestly clear from the Greek text, in which those twain words, “only” and “true,” connected by one article, be referred unto the predicate, not unto the subject, unto God, not unto the Father, hina ginōskōsi se ton monon alēthinon theon. It maketh a great difference whether the word “only” be referred unto the subject or unto the predicate; for if it be referred unto the subject, the sense is, the Father and no other is the true God; but if unto the predicate, then the sense will be, the Father indeed is that God who alone is the true God; but it is not excluded that the Son also is that God who alone is the true God. Someone else answereth that it should be expounded, “Thee the only true God,” that is, Thee who alone art the true God, not however Thee to be Him who alone is the true God, but he noticeth not that both particles “only” and “true” be joined with God by one article, not with the Father, wherefore it is to be referred unto God, not unto the Father. But if we were to admit that only the Father is called the true God in this place, yet that would not at all help the cause of the adversaries. For neither is the Father alone called the true God, to exclude Christ, who is the Son, and of the same nature with the Father, but to exclude idols and false gods, who be of another nature from God. For this is what Christ willeth to say: that eternal life is placed in this, that men detest all other gods and idols of the Gentiles, and turn unto Thee, who alone among all gods art the true God. Whence that word “alone” excludeth other diverse gods, but not Christ, who is not a diverse God from the Father, and the sense is, that they may know Thee the only true God, that is, alone among all gods. In which sense also Paul, 1 Thessalonians 1:9, saith, “Ye turned to God from idols to serve the living and true God”; he opposeth the true God unto idols. Unto this also pertaineth, and this reason, that just as the name of Lord is given unto the Son, when one Lord is said, not to exclude the Father, who is certainly Lord, and the name of Spirit is given unto the Holy Spirit, not to exclude the Father and the Son, who be also Spirit, but by a certain attribution and accommodation, so also the name of the true God is given unto the Father alone by a certain attribution, not to exclude the Son.

But the adversary thinketh that Christ is excluded from this, that He distinguisheth Himself from that only true God, when He addeth, “and Jesus Christ, whom Thou hast sent.” But rather the opposite was to be concluded from this. For when He addeth, “and whom Thou hast sent,” He rather joineth Himself with that true God, so that the sense is, that they may know both Thee and whom Thou hast sent to be the only true God. For the Latin speech also admitteth such a construction, unto which that in 1 Corinthians 9:6 is like, “Or I only and Barnabas, have not we power?” and the thing itself seemeth to require it. Since eternal life is said to be placed equally in the knowledge of the Father and of Christ, each is equally called the true God.

Objection. The third argument that they bring forth against the Holy Trinity is from 1 Corinthians 8:6, where the Holy Spirit clearly teacheth that there is one God the Father, from whom are all things, who is also distinguished from Christ, insofar as Christ is one Lord, through whom are all things. Therefore, Christ is not that one God who is the Father.

Response: It is marvelous either the ignorance or the rashness of the adversaries, that they notice not that in this place Paul neither separateth the one God from Christ, nor the one Lord from the Father. For he establisheth this, that for us Christians, there be not many gods and lords, but one God and one Lord. But if the Father were another God and Lord, and Christ another, there would be twain gods and twain lords, which overturneth the whole purpose of Paul, so that it is necessary to say that the Father and Christ be one God and one Lord. Then, it is the same to be God and Lord. For that God is Lord, there is no doubt; and that the Lord, who is Lord in a divine manner, and opposed unto idols (as it is taken in this place), is certainly also God. Therefore, when Paul saith that the one God is the Father, he also acknowledgeth Him as the one Lord, and when he saith that the one Lord is Christ, he acknowledgeth Him to be the one God, and just as from God he excludeth not the Lord, so neither from the Lord doth he exclude God. The conjecture of Socinus is frivolous, founded on those particles, “from whom are all things,” and “through whom are all things”; for these particles be elsewhere in the Scriptures attributed unto the same God, as Romans 11:36, “For of Him, and through Him, and to Him, are all things.” Therefore, they have no force to exclude Christ from true deity. Furthermore, by a certain attribution and accommodation, “from whom are all things” is said of the Father; “through whom are all things,” of Christ, not that each doth not belong unto both, but that one is chiefly attributed unto one, the other chiefly unto the other. Wherefore, Socinus is mistaken, thinking that the particle “through whom are all things” denoteth a secondary cause, since the same particle is also attributed unto God Himself elsewhere, by which also in this place it is to be believed to be attributed unto Christ. Especially since the scope of the Apostle is to show that there is only one God and Lord; but with Socinus’s exposition admitted, there would be twain gods and lords, one from whom are all things, another through whom are all things. Albeit the same Apostle, Ephesians 4:5, without such particles, absolutely affirmeth that there is one Lord, and one God, and Father; so that nothing of mystery is to be estimated in such particles for distinguishing God from Lord in themselves.
